Worth spending the day to explore. I always enjoy Odaiba, from the train ride across the spectacular Rainbow Bridge to the wide spaces peppered with architecturally interesting buildings. As this was Christmas season, the lights were enchanting as was the Christmas-themed illumination up on the TV tower building. A Christmas market was in full swing giving the impression of Europe; characters dressed in cosplay costumes and one man with a lighted crab strapped to his back brought back the reality of quirky Japan where the unusual is usual. Very convenient Japanese food court in the basement of DiverCity (you can't miss the giant Gundam at the front entrance). The Hokkaido french fries from Calbee Plus, also at the basement, is a must try.
Great View from the Carousel. This is an artificial island where lots of Toyota cars are seen, including the older brands. The view is very nice at the top if you take the carousel

Amazing Day Out. We had been to Odaiba on a Day visit over the weekend. Great place for relaxation, shopping, attractions and Just FUN. Try to go here by Train- Yurikamome line, you will have the best view of the city. We got the front deck in the train so the view was still amazing.

1/1 Gundam view @ Diver City. Lucky to be able to visit the legendary 1/1 scale Gundam at Diver City located at Odaiba, as well as the schedule broadcast of Gundam screening. The outdoor park is a serene place for couple to have their own time, especially during cold season.

Great area to stay or visit.. We stayed in Odaiba at the Grand Pacific Le Daiba for just over a week and found it to be a great area for dining, shopping and attractions. There's lots of good shopping at Diver City, Aqua City and Venus Fort. Aqua City also has a lot of good restaurants for western tourists. Sizzler, La Pausa, Eggs n Things and Kua'aina being a few. Just through the Venus Fort shopping mall is the Toyota Mega Web which is so much fun if you like cars. There's also a rather large Ferris wheel there.All around Odaiba was a great area to stay in just outside of the city.
.. Love the arcade. Stayed at the nikko hotel 5 years ago which was very nice. Great views of rainbow bridge at night. Lots of restaurants and shopping facilities.

Needs a full day to explore. Buy a Yurikamome one day open ticket for Yen820 per person and you can hop on and off the monorail all day. We spent a full day there. Architecture feels futuristic. In December most attractions do not open until 11am, so we checked out the beach and rode the monorail enjoying the fantastic views. Worth going on a clear day. The free Toyota Megaweb and Panasonic exhibitions were excellent, there were no queues on a weekday morning in December. We got to try various driving simulations, ride a Winglet (like a Segway) and even try a massage chair! Don't bother paying for the Museum of Emerging Technologies unless you have kids under 10, and be prepared for the hordes of school kids on day trips. Venus Fort with its artificial sky was incredible and right now they have Xmas illuminations with synchronized lights and music. Unforgettable! We tried the 'all you can eat' buffet restaurant in Decks - not up to the standard we had elsewhere in Tokyo - but it was OK. Since it was dark about 4:30pm we also got to see the illuminated Ferris wheel and Rainbow Bridge.

Day trip!. This place is definitely a must see while in Tokyo, just took the monorail. This had excellent views of the city but it can get busy so expect to stand at rush hour! We spent the morning at the Tsukiji Market then went to Odaiba in the afternoon, we were there for about half a day and that wasn't enough! Odaiba has awesome shopping centres filled with affordable high street shops unlike expensive Shinjuku! Spot the ferris wheel, mini statue of liberty and the rainbow bridge!There is a cat cafe on route from the train station to the shopping area, It looks cute but it smells like cat poop (funnily enough)!I would definitely recommend checking Odaiba out!

Tokyo Bay Spectacular!. Divided by the Yumeno Ohashi Bridge, Tokyo Bay is in two parts, Odaiba and Ariake. Both areas of this man made island have something for everyone and is very popular with foreign visitors for it's first class hotels and restaurants and shopping malls, and for locals alike looking for weekend entertainment.Odaiba has possibly the best location in Tokyo, and the less overcrowding of the inner city, which is a why so many choose this area for holidays.Odaiba has the most resort-like atmosphere for Tokyo shopping. This seaside port town can offer everything from the best shopping mall's; Aqua City (Disney Store and Daiso), Decks (Madame Tussauds Wax Museum and Tokyo Joypolis) and DiverCity. While Ariake has Palette Town and Venus Fort with La La Port a little further out to Toyosu Station.Odaiba has a free shuttle bus service and runs a service from around 11am to 7pm daily. Stops are Miraikan, Grand Pacific Hotel, Aqua City, Hotel Nikko, DiverCity,Tokyo Teleport Stn, Palette Town (Venus Fort) and Wangan Fuji TV Studio.Transport to inner city Tokyo is on the Yurikamome monorail or by train on the Rinkai Line from Ariake.Odaiba is the home of Disney resort neighbourhood hotels, Grand Pacific, Hotel Nikko, Sunroute Ariake, and all have free shuttle buses to and from the Tokyo Disney Resorts, Disneyland and Disney Sea.Venus Fort is spectacular in itself, has a unique ceiling that looks like the sky outside and is very authentic Italian town, with amazing fountain feature. Close by is Palette Town with several attractions, Toyota Mega Web Theme Park, Daikanransha 'Giant In The Sky' ferris wheel, Tokyo Leisureland, a noisy fun filled game arcade open 24 hours a day, Panasonic Centre, open to public to view the latest in Panasonic products and electronics, Tokyo Big Sight, incredible conference and exhibition centre (the Tokyo Motor Show is held here annually), and in Odaiba, Fuji Television studios, open for tours and views from the central dome in an inspiring modern aged building. This is the most photographed building in Tokyo Bay! Turns all colourful at festive season being used as a backdrop for Christmas illuminations in Odaiba.Along the marine park are running tracks, and gardens and cruise piers.Top all that off with some of the best shopping, entertainment, views, close to Haneda Airport, and hour from Narita Airport, this is the new Tokyo, modern, inspiring, and a must visit for all visitors to Tokyo.Stay a few days and you'll enjoy this part of Tokyo as much as we do, and always choose Odaiba as our base when in Tokyo. The inner city is not far away, yet the views from here to the downtown Tokyo are breathtaking, off the Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo Tower, Skytree, and port of Tokyo, you'll enjoy being here and experiencing all Odaiba/Ariake has to offer.
TOYOTA MEGA WEB. Excellent venue if you are a car enthusiast. Lots of interesting cars on display, both historic and new.

An entertainment district where you can easily spend a day. O'Daiba is a popular shopping and entertainment district on a man made island in Tokyo Bay. We took the Yurikamome Line from Shimbashi station to O'daiba. There are many interesting attractions in Odaiba, the Rainbow Bridge, the Trick Eye Museum, Toyota Mega Web, lots of shopping, a Ferris wheel etc. We spend half a day there, and I've penned down our trip in Tokyo in my blog at http://idylsherry.blogspot.fr/2014/11/japan-trip-tokyo_20.html.

Must go, on a date!. This is Tokyo, official, unofficial date spot!! You go here if you want take someone somewhere kinda romantic. Lots of restaraunt and food places to choose from. With a great view of TokyoHint: Walk to the little island park thats near the rainbow bridge, the view is worth it.

Fun place for a decent price : ). Let me start off by saying there is a lot to do in Odaiba XD I think you need an entire day, maybe even two, to actually finish exploring and experiencing this place. There is just so much to see in so little time. Aqua City, Palette Town, and Decks are definitely a must see when visiting Odaiba. Unfortunately those were the only places I could finish exploring in one day. There are large shopping malls, many tasty restaurants, museums, activities, large Gundam statue, and more. Its a great place for anyone to enjoy; couples, family, friends, solo, its a place you have to go to at least once while you're in Japan. I highly recommend Lego Land and Madame Tussad's Wax Museum at Decks, and Venus Fort at Palette Town.

A Great Island!. Be prepared to spend an entire day on this island esp if you are planning to shop here as both the Aqua City and Diver City shopping center are mega sized shopping mall!Be sure to check out the Palette Town and Decks which we did not managed to visit due to time constraint. Look out for the Ferris wheel in Palette Town! Not forgetting about the replica of the Statue of Liberty and the "life sized" Gundam statue which we missed it as we did not explore further out from Diver City after hours of shopping.Make sure you check out this island when you are in Tokyo!
Super nice night view. Super nice night view at odaiba such as Rainbow Bridge which can be taken from The Decks, Aquacity. Palette Town and a big Gundam at Diver City.
Great!. Odaiba is great.Quiet, super clean. Cool bridge.the man made beach is amazing. Truly must see in japan.

Daikanransha (Ferris Wheel). The ferris wheel has multi-coloured cabins with warmed seats, making up for the small size (4 pax to a cabin is about right). The ride takes 16 min and cost us 4000¥ for a family of 7. The night scenery is average, and the rainbow bridge partially obscured by the mammoth fuji tv building. The adjoining shopping complex, Venus Fort, is worth a visit for its Venetian-themed interior design.

A must when in Japan. This is a really great part of Japan. Modern buildings, and you could just stand there for hours and marvel at the architecture and structures. Plenty of shops and the Venus fort is very much like Las Vegas hotels with the shopping mall and fake blue sky. We walked all day around the shops and along the water side. Fantastic sites and atmosphere. Loved it!

A Must Visit. Odaiba waterfront has so so many attractions. Any visitor to Tokyo must create time to visit Odaiba, if they have a day to spare. There are many attractions and sometimes it may not be possible to visit them all. The trains to Odaiba are automated driverless trains. The Rainbow Bridge is a sight to behold as well.
Great place to shop. There are tons of shops and it's right on the beach, so you can enjoy a day of shopping and spend the afternoon on the beach. There are also was museums, a legoland and more
Great Tokyo Sunset. Odaiba wasn't really on our list of places to see while visiting Tokyo but ended up there one day and the view of the city at sunset was brilliant and definitely worth it.

Back to the future. Went here initially to check out the gundam statue and science musuem and then woaaaaaaah... was truly taken aback by how futuristic this district is. It looks like a city within a city like I felt it was Atlantis above water and then I found out it is actually a man-made island which could be part of the reason it looks like this. It is also located close to the waterside so has good sea views and stuff too. Major sights for me found here - gundam statue, science musuem (Mirikian i believe it's called) and the fuji center building which contributes greatly to the futuristic architecture of this place. If you are in Tokyo you should definitely check it out fo sure yo!

Interesting New Japan. Odaiba is by the waters and therefore you can walk along the beach (novelty in Asia). There are several plazas for shopping, games and food. Most of the arcades and games are of the newest characters so it caters for youth and younger people. It is still however a nice place to spend an afternoon as there are many interesting independent shops. Daiso is also there (a shop which sells most things at fixed price of 100 Yen)). That's an interesting shop indeed. We recommend you stay till night falls (which is quite early in November 5.30pm) as Odaiba lights up and it's beautiful. Don't forget to look out for Gundam outside of Diver Plaza.

Larger area than you think. We were staying at Tokyo Towers across from Odaiba and could see the beautiful coloured ferris wheel at night from our balcony. We went over the check it out, which takes few subway stops and then the monorail type line to get there. The tickets certainly weren't cheap on that! We went over for dinner and to look around - probably a bit of a disappointment as it was hard to find anything. We did go to one of the shopping centres which had a whole floor of amusements, one level of restaurants and about 5 levels of shopping. Could have spent a whole lot more time shopping

Nice view, malls, and outlets. The scenery around Odaiba is so beautiful especially at night. It's a place where you can browse around the malls and shops in different buildings, see the old Toyota museum (A must!!), visit the quite compact, but beautiful Venus outlet, see a giant Gundum, and then see the statue of liberty right by the bridge. I love it there!

Just a whole lot of shopping. There are a lot of museums and places to visit. Amusement rides, things like that. I mainly walked around Decks Tokyo and Aqua-City. A lot of walking and window shopping, so be sure to take plenty of rest breaks. There are lots of benches overlooking the water so take some time out and enjoy the beautiful outdoors. Especially at night when the rainbow bridge is lit up.

Fun Day in Odaiba. We could easily spend an entire day (and more) on Odaiba Island. There is so much to do - sight-see, Rainbow Bridge, Diver City, Ooedo Onsen, Venus Fort, Aqua City and more. A free shuttle is available on the island. Loved the Onsen. Disliked that there is very little to no English signage to get around - we had to find information desks to help us.

There is something for everyone. Odaiba is a huge entertainment/shopping/leisure area near the Port of Tokyo. Probably the best comparison might be Sentosa in Singapore but Odaiba is a much, much bigger. There are three main areas (Diver City, Venus Forts, Decks). Anyway, I went here today and arrived at around 4pm thinking 4 hours was more than enough to see all the attractions. Boy, was I wrong! I spent two hours alone at Diver City and barely finished Venus Forts. I never made it to Decks. In addition to shopping, there is a vintage car museum on the basement level of Venus Fort called "History Garage" where you can see some vintage cars. There is also a ferris wheel and a huge arcade next to it that has batting cages, pool, coin dozer games, regular arcade games etc. (You can also go to Round 1 at Diver City for a more upscale experience but it might be more crowded). I'm sure the views of Tokyo Bay are breathtaking on a sunny day. I highly recommend you come here for the sites, shopping, and entertainment.

Touristy. we took the sumaida river cruise to reach Odaiba. The place is a creation to cater to tourists with a statue of Liberty right at its entrance. Overall average in case u trying to look at Japan and everything Japanese

Lots of things to do. My husband and I bought a 1 Day pass for 720 yen and rode on the monorail (Yurikamone). There is stuff to do at almost every stop. We rode by a motor sport area and decided to just stop by to check it out. The admission was free and we got to see a lot of cool cars which my husband is into. We saw some racers there. We didn't know who they were but one of them had a line of people waiting to take pictures and get autograph from him. We stood in line and did the same even though we didn't know who he was. Then we went to the Mega Web to check out Toyota cars. Since we were there the week before Halloween, there was a Halloween party at one of the stops, we got there and saw a bit of J-Pop Idols performing and there were a lot of people standing on the bridge watching them. There are a few shopping areas if that's what you're into.

One day is not enough here... There is a pet haven here, inside the mall. O God. One floor for pet stores. Cute ones. High quality stuff and good interior design. There is also 100Y store (which is not 100Y anymore, to be exact the price per item was 110Y), but it worth the price.There is also a view to the sea and at the other area there is a beach, liberty statue, rainbow bridge, sega dock. Also there is plenty of food choices.When the night falls in, riding the train heading to Odaiba would be a great experience. They're using a different kind of train (I don't know what it called). The edgy ones, different with their regular train. The train station also looks edgy.I went there on winter, so at night, standing at the Deck was freaking freezing. :)

New futuristic part of the Tokyo. Well this is one completely new part of the city with some truly amazing architecture, great shopping places, beaches, amazing views of Tokyo and Rainbow bridge and some truly unique and strange attractions... Statue of Liberty!? Full scale Gundam!? K Museum... amazing Fuji TV building... just to name a few... and of course - Yurikamome train - truly great experience and most efficient way to come to this part of the city...
Great fun shopping area.. Great fun place with many shopping malls. Little bit far and expensive to get too. But totally worth the day I spent there.

Best place for shopping in Tokyo. Found shopping here the most pleasant. It was less messy (compared to shinjuku and shibuya) and catered clothes more towards the mass market young working adults (compared to ginza). There is plenty of food choices here as well. Palette Town, Diver's City and Aqua City are all within walking distances from the train station. For potato chip fans, Diver's city also boasts a Calbee cafe serving hot fresh potato chips.

Futuristic. Dismayingly? no this is for real. If you want to see a futuristic urban setting this is the place. The Fuji building architecture is spectacular. The shopping areas are super modern, miss than the U.S. great place for a amend stall with street performance and colorful characters. Also, excellent views of Tokyo, and an automated driverless train that gets you there. 5 stars.

really well designed 'city within a city'. for JR pass users you can take the JR yamanote line to Shimbashi station and transfer to Yurikamome Line to Odaiba. (¥320 per trip).Odaiba has a lot of good spots to hang out. The view of the Rainbow Bridge from the Decks is incredible. i suggest to walk along the Rainbow Bridge if you have time (and energy) to spare. The city view at around 6pm this time of year is really good. Keep in mind the wind might be very strong.Also visit the Venus Fort. It has a great interior design.

Nice Place to Explore. I went to Odaiba via Shiodome (Yurikamome Line). The view on the way to Odaiba is wonderful. The main highlight in Odaiba will be the huge Gundam Statue which stands in front of Diver City Tokyo Plaza. As I went during a weekday, there will less of a crowd in Odaiba which is nice to explore without being too packed to move around. Other highlights in Odaiba will be the Ferris Wheel, a "mini Statue of Liberty" and a great view of the Rainbow Bridge.

night view and shopping. odaiba has lots of shopping and dinning options. easy but expansive access through trains. we experienced typhoon the night we visited odaiba, walking between the malls became difficult. views of the liberty, rainbow bridge, and tokyo at night from train was great. in a liquor store in dive city, we found that a bottle of blue lable/ royal solute was 30% cheaper than ginza, even cheaper than duty free shop

So many things to do there!. Here you are a little video I made in 4K about Odaiba : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nBAx5qJKaE4Also know as the official beach of Tokyo, Odaiba’s construction was initially started to protect Tokyo with a series of six fortresses islands build in the 1850s. Today only the No. 3 Battery Fortress or Dai-San Daiba (第三台場) is open to the public since 1928. Usually empty this reconverted battery is an amazingly peaceful park with a stunning view on both Odaiba beach as well as the Rainbow Bridge! Talking about the Rainbow Bridge, did you know that its real name was actually the “Shuto Expressway No. 11 Daiba Route - Port of Tokyo Connector Bridge” and that the name Rainbow Bridge was later decided by the public after its construction which ended in 1993?But Odaiba is much more than this beautiful bridge, Odaiba in its actual form was shaped since the 1990s with some major commercial outlets, residential and leisure areas including the famous Fuji Television Bldg, the Miraikan (the National Museum of Emerging Science and Innovation), Tokyo Big Sight (or Tokyo International Exhibition Center), Aqua City, The Panasonic Center, the Museum of Maritime Science, the MegaWeb or Toyota’s world largest Showroom where you can actually test all Toyota’s car available in japan, a replica of the Statue of Liberty, the Sega Joypolis (Arcade wonderland), a life seize Gundam statue and finally a stunning onsen the Oedo Onsen Monogatari Hot Springs, an Edo ear like open and close onsen that everybody have to visit once in their life when traveling or living in Tokyo!Visiting Odaiba cannot be done in one day, there is so much to discover there and we strongly advise you to plan ahead in order to not miss anything that this place has to offer you!
terrific. full of everything & with a great sea view . At night u can c the rainbow bridge & capture nice photos for the statue of liberty

i love the Giant Gundam. One of Tokyo's landmark these days are spotted in Odaiba; The Giant Gundam and Japan Liberty. It's located 30 minutes by train from JR Hamamatsucho/Tokyo. It's free of charge and very beautiful at evening.

Love Odaiba !!. Such a beautiful area with many shopping options. Great big stores and you can enjoy walking on the decks of the malls facing the rainbow bridge. Love going there during weekdays when it is less crowded and always enjoy the fact they have everything i would look for. I say its perfect for all ages with different attractions around there.
o for the view and the shopping!. Great area with loads of shopping (Aqua City) and one of the best views of Tokyo skyline and the Rainbow Bridge you'll find!

A bundle of awesome!. Odaiba to me is like a collection of great things put in an island.It features a multiple of must-see shops, business centers and landmarks. A stunning view of metropolitan Tokyo can be seen from Odaiba as well - it looks best during sunset, in my opinion.

You have to be there to love. Loved everything. The view especially tone the water and city. Monorail ride into the island itself was worth as you travel over the rainbow bridge and watch Ferris wheel and great architecture around the place.

Great introduction to Japan!. There is such a lot to see and do here! We were lucky to be staying in the area, so had time to walk around properly. Although there are four shopping centres, if shopping isn't your bag, then there are plenty of other things, including a huge car showroom, fun fair, Fuji TV (well worth having a look around, although you won't really understand anything) - and even a Statue of Liberty!

A day trip at Tokyo Bay. It's a place best for family or anyone with many things to do. Getting there can be a hassle but we the tokyo city bus which takes us straight to palette town where the ferries wheel is. Odaiba is a well-known entertainment and shopping district, located on an artificially constructed island within Tokyo Bay. At 115 meters tall, this Ferris wheel is easily among the largest in the world. Don't miss one of the world's tallest Ferris wheels, which is as high as the second viewing platform of the Eiffel Tower. From Toyota to Onsen Theme Park, rainbow bridge, shopping and the ganman structure.Worth a day trip here with many things to do. http://jacqsowhat.blogspot.sg/2014/10/tokyo-japan-day-4-imperial-palace.html

Megaweb Toyota at Odaiba Tokyo.. The Toyota Megaweb and the history garage located in the Venus fort shopping mall on Odaiba island in Tokyo are must visits for car nuts. Both attractions are free to enter. Megaweb is exclusively Toyota with vehicles on static display but test drives are available around a 3kilometre circuit so long as a Japanese or an International drivers licences are held. The history garage as a wide range of makes ranging from a Cadilac, FIAT, VW, Citroen, Renault, Isuzu, Honda as well as a Delorean and others. A must visit for car lovers while in Tokyo for sure.

Visited By Default. Our water cruise ended in Odaiba, so gave us a chance to look around. Admittedly we didn't have a lot of time to check it out but we did go on the big wheel which, until the London Eye opened, was the biggest in the world. Seems like a lot of shopping malls, in addition to the beach. Was easy to get back to Shimbashi on the private monorail (IC cards work).

Odaiba. Went to Odaiba several times in late September early October, easy to get around and the sights are spectacular, The Tokyo Big Sight is amazing (a convention centre), there is also a Statue of Liberty and Ganman statue and ferris wheel that lights up at night. We went to the Tennis Open at Ariake Coliseum - great place to visit and experience.

Cool place for day trip. Is recommend if you have few days in Tokyo as this attraction is kinda urban.Easily spend a day activities here, walking around and the fun part is visiting to Toyota Centre. Come with international driving licence so you can pick a car to test drive! There's a huge Gundum display too! (I am not sure is seasonal or what)

A little bit of home in Tokyo. Odaiba has some of the best Western shopping in Tokyo, with stores like Old Navy, Forever 21, Babies R Us, and more There are a series of different malls, including Venus Fort which is all outlets. Easy to get to by monorail or boat. Can be crowded, and there always seems to be a Festival or special event going on.

Generaly this is an outlet centre. It is built on reclaimed land not bad for shopping and eating tax free so carry passports at all times if buying goods. Do your research first before you go its all on line.

We love Odaiba - a great place for the whole family. Odaiba is well worth visiting, it's unlike the rest of Tokyo - spacious areas, beautiful landscape and not so crowded! There is lots to see and do here for families with several large and entertainment shopping complexes - Aqua City, Tokyo Decks, Diver City, Palette Town. Shopping hours are 11am-10pm and each is full of many restaurants. Aqua City has movie complex, great amusement arcade and Mamtoko Fuji Kids Café and play area which is great for toddlers/pre schoolers and younger kids. Decks has Sega Joypolis which is a huge indoor amusement arcade with a rollercoaster and other rides all inside - my boys loved it here. Also Legoland, 4D Cinema and retro pinball arcade is at Decks. Diver City has the huge Gundam statue which kids will love and it looks especially good at night with lights and smoke. Palette Town has a massive ferris wheel and amusement arcade, Toyota Mega Web and Venus Fort Shopping Centre - beautiful place to visit even if its only window shopping. All have great shopping and better value than shopping in Sydney! Take the Yurikamome Line to get to Odaiba or from Asakusa you can catch a space age boat called the Himiko along the Sumida River. Odaiba is especially beautiful at night with the Rainbow Bridge and various cruise ships all beautifully lit up.

car museum in Odaiba. Mostly went to Odaiba to go to car museum. We had seen a show on television about it. Was a little disappointed since I thought there would be more cars, but the ones that were there were nice. Other than that it was mostly a mall with lots of things for children to do. We had no children with us, so this was not important to us.

Of little interest to me. Apart from the Miraikan, which is in the same area and is excellent, I was disappointed with Odaiba. Consisting mainly of large shopping malls with lots of shops full of tat, I really found little here that was worth the trip. The train trip across the Rainbow Bridge was good, but generally I was disappointed - apart from when I visited on a Sunday when hundreds of weirdly dressed locals hang around the area dressed as manga characters, and who spent their day posing for each other.

modern place. buildings wise this place is going for a futuristic look. i was quite impressed by fuji tv building. went to Decks for the trick art museum, which was great. staff was pleasant and the place is interesting. however, you do need a little bit imagination and photography skills to get the most out of this place.also visited takoyaki museum, an absolute let down. venus fort was a let down too. nothing much there

Afternoon + Night Is the Best Option Visiting Odaiba. Away from the city center, once a battery (fort) to protect Tokyo (call Edo in the past), and now one of the most popular tourist attractions - the Odaiba (お台場, 御台場) is a large man-made island in Tokyo Bay. The name Odaiba comes from the original daiba (fort, battery) that was built in 1953 to protect Edo from being attacked by sea, the primary threat being Commodore Matthew Perry's Black Ships from US. The original plan was to have 11 batteries on 6 island fortresses, but only 5 batteries were finished. Today the 6th battery became the foundation in developing the modern Odaiba and, the 3rd battery was purposely left there as a monument, which can be seen just under the Rainbow Bridge. The major development started from 1990s by Tokyo governor Shun'ichi Suzuki; he wanted to transfer this artificial island into the model of future city life. It was not very successful until late 90’s when it became a tourist and recreation area. Some hotels, big shopping malls, and several big companies started moving their headquarters to Odaiba. With the improvement of transportation and the desire to have a place to leisure, the Odaiba become a popular destination in the Tokyo area. It took us about 70 minutes to reach Odaiba via a water bus from Asakusa. When we were approaching Odaiba, we passed the beautiful Rainbow Bridge and saw a man-made beach in front of the island with the Fuji TV building on the backdrop. This is a large area; we spent the whole afternoon and night but could not see them all. They have free Bay Shuttle bus stops at major locations; you need to find the small sign of the bus stops in order to take the free ride. Once we got off the Water Bus, we saw a Statue of Liberty on our right and then entered a huge Aqua City Odaiba shopping mall. There are total 4 big shopping malls in Odaiba. We only had time to see briefly 2 of them. If you love shopping, this is a paradise, and you can find almost all the famous brands here. Make sure to get the floor guide if you want to find a particular store. Be aware that goods in Japan are quite expensive. The other unique building is the Fuji TV Building – Fuji TV headquarters. It costs 550 yen to access the observatory deck housed in the sphere shaped of the building. If the weather is good, you can see as far as the Fuji Mountain and, of course, most of the Tokyo skyscrapers. We stayed quite late in order to take a night photo of the Rainbow Bridge, Fuji TV Building and the Giant Sky Wheel. Don’t forget to bring your tripod if you want to take the night photos. You can go there by train, bus or water bus. We took a water bus to Odaiba and returned by train. You can check their website for more information.

The bridge did not light up. Odaiba is quiet far so make sure to reserve at least half day for this. I dont really find the place amazing although the view overlooking the bridge is great. Few activities can be done here like shopping and well more shopping. Although for cgeap finds this is not the place to be. If you live cars dont miss the Toyota center where they showcase some of the cars you can only imagine. I was disappointed to find though that they don't light the bridge at night in colors as seen in pictures. We waited until night time only to see white lights. And we only went here for the rainbow bridge..:(

Excellent place for shopping. You can find anything you want in Odaiba while having a nice meal or going for the fun of Joypolis. The most original Venus Fort and its skylike roof put you in the romantic atmosphere of a night in Italy. You can easily spend the day there and might even come back.

Lovely place! so peaceful. I love it here... it was so quiet and less busier compared to other tourist area. There are shops which are affordable but nonetheless there are areas you can visit and stroll. Lego land , though small is here as well.

Excellent place. Calm and serene. Best at evening.. This place is beautiful, calm amd serene, best for couples. But you can go there with family. Evening time js the best time to visit to see the sunset and watch the raimbow bridge lit up.

Good foods. Odaiba was the only place that I never thought to get there easily when looking through the map. I was amazed how easy to travel there, the sub-way connection just brought us there within no time. Spectacular view, restaurants offered excellent menu with good selections.

Shopping, Rainbow Bridge, Food and Souvenirs. Shopping and Shopping. If you like shopping it is probably the biggest shopping (area wise). There is Outlet where there is a nice car museum as well worth visiting. A massive robot in front of the Diver City and pretty cool souvenir and little food things in Aqua City.If you are coming from Asakusa I recommend taking the the Ferry which has good sight seeing.

Tourist trap. Unless you're traveling with kids, do yourself a favor and skip this man-made part of the city. This is the boardwalk of Tokyo without the history. Overpriced mediocre food, arcades, waterfront, etc.
Nice to visit. Spent a couple hours hanging out here with a 4 year old. If you have time to kill this is a nice addition to the day.

ODAIBA offers a great time-out for the business traveller. For the business traveller wanting to take a break from prowling the halls of TOKYO BIG SIGHT, the ODIABA bayside area is a welcome respite.Get off at DAIBA train station, which is something like an interchange. You may also hop onto the free ODAIBA shuttle bus that loops the entire bay area. The buildings adjoining the interchange are all colourful malls, chocked full of shops and restaurants: namely Venus Fort, Aqua City and DiverCity.First up, VENUS FORT: It's just next to TOYOTA MEGAWEB, Japan's largest ferris wheel. The interior of Venus Fort is reminiscent of Macau's Venetian. Not a very busy mall, Venus houses a eclectic mix of mid-range small specialist boutiques, selling clothes (that look like they're made for size 0s only), shoes and luggage bags. One particular shop selling Japanese made leather shoes and hand-made leather accessories stood out. There's a small food court on the upper floor where you can have a good meal for under US$10. A mixture of Japanese, Indian, Korean and of course, the compulsory Japanese inspired western food are available.Next, AQUA CITY: One side of the building, complete with boardwalk, faces Japan's miniaturised version of the 'Statue of Liberty' and the gardens that fringe the bayside. Cat and dog lovers must not miss PET PLUS, on the ground floor, very near TOYS R US. This is a haven for your beloved pooches and felines. A stunning variety of pet products and grooming services are available, some never seen before outside of Japan, I think. Genuine Coca Cola collectibles can be bought at the brand's shop. Along the same grain, an entire floor is dedicated to vintage. From the products sold to a 1950's 'Happy Days' inspired milkshake bar. Delightful. Do also visit the TOKYO TRICK ART MUSEUM. It houses numerous pieces of art work done in 3D which will leave your mind in knots. Experience illusions guaranteed to tickle your funny bone! AND there is a DISNEY store here too! Oh joy! Pick up your fave DISNEY products without having to be at Tokyo Disneyland. Don't miss the shop where you may buy characteristic Japanese snacks as gifts for the folks back home. Tokyo Banana, of course. While there, check out LA BOHEME Italian restaurant on the 4th floor. Their huge dome shaped windows that look out to the bay will serve as a romantic backdrop as you wine and dine. You may be met with something unusual there. As he serves you your meal, make friends with MR ILIOS GARCIA: Japan's only Japanese-speaking Spanish doctor of natural medicine. I promise you, you will leave La Boheme feeling not just satisfied from your meal, but much wiser too. Go figure, folks! Lastly, DiverCity: A modern mall that houses not just the usual international brands like UNIQLO and OLD NAVY, it houses ubiquitous Japanese brands like GLICO, HELLO KITTY, MORINAGA and CALBEE. You may pick up several pieces of very reasonably priced smart casuals from OLD NAVY for the whole family. A pair of skinny jeans cost just US$10. Fans of GUNDAM will be thrilled at a 20m tall fibre glass model of one of the characters just outside the food court. Their food court is huge. Various permutations of Japanese and Korean food abound. Do note their food court etiquette: return your own tray to the stall from which you bought your meal. Prices reasonable, about US$10 per person.

Nice place for a weekend hangout. I went for a weekend afternoon hang out to this place. Nice to see rainbow bridge from there. Sunset is beautiful. Snd lighting st night gives a goot shot for photographers. For playing at the beach pre permission has to take. I can see families came for weekend camping.

AMAZING!!!. I loved Odaiba so much, it's the one place I never fail to visit every trip. There really is something for everyone here, and even the Yurikamome ride out gives you a panoramic view of Tokyo from the Rainbow Bridge.Best part, hands down? The giant Ferris Wheel, Daikanransha. One of the tallest in the world, and at night the view is indescribable (also quite romantic if you're with "someone" haha).Beyond that, there's video games galore, a Gundam cafe, and lots of shopping.Get your picture taken in front of the life-sized giant Gundam, and also in front of the Statue of Liberty! Oh, and as a bonus, Pokemon stole the names of most places from its first generation, from around this area!
Excellent Place to Visit. Stayed at New Nikko Hotel! Great City..Aqua Shopping Center great too...near train station. Beautiful Scenery

LOVED this place . As soon as we got out of the modern and clean subway station we got on one of the free shuttle busses. We randomly got off at one of the stops and stepped right out onto the best view of Tokyo harbour. We lingered around and had a drink and dinner while watching the stunning view
sensory overload in a good way. this place has so much to do for a family or its a good place to keep the kids entertained for many hours. Video games, shops, restaurants great hotels too

My favorite place in Tokio. I don't know why, but I love this place. There are so many things to do, but even if you just look at the skyline of Tokyo at night, it is beautiful. Also the monorail is a pretty neat experience. Odaiba feels like the future.

Great for parents and teens.. We took the subway out. I looked the name of the station. Tokyo teleport....first we walked over to the Diver City mall to see the giant Gundam. Pretty cool! Then the kids went to the Sega Joypolis while the adults found a restaurant with a great view of Tokyo bay. We met up with the kids who wanted to dip a toe in the bay (we live on the other side of the pacific in a coastal California town. It had to be done) We also got some pictures of the mini Statue of Liberty, enjoyed a sunset, the view of colorful boats on the bay, and the striking rainbow bridge. We finished by taking the monorail back across the bridge. A great day!
Access & Entertainment. Great access by Rainbow bridge or boat.Place mainly for those searching for shopping and entertainment

Nice place to take my boy. Awesome stop at the car history museum and the Odaiba Decks... lots to do from lego discovery to a mall and an amazing arcade. If you don't speak Japanese don't waste your time finding the go-carts, they only allow conversational speaking Japanese to participate ~major disappointment to my son
No atmosphere. Disappointed. Went there 11 years ago and nothing really had changed. Didnt have any atmosphere or good shopping

Entertainment area. This area is great whatever the weather. Lots of places to eat, shop and be entertained. I would recommend the wheel for great views. Car enthusiasts should pop into the Toyota store so much more than a car showroom. Lots to see and do for all ages.

Definitely must see island!. Spend a day in this area. Seen once 10 years ago... Great to be back and be surprised again! Food, attractions, great views from dusk to dawn! Hundreds of pics made from any angle! Rainbow bridge, buildings with dancing lights in the evening. Boats like toys on the Tokyo bay. Everything makes you smile. Just get there! Mega web is a must see place. Garage with old times cars. Fashion shopping. Just get to the first stopping in Odaiba, and make your walking through the island... Monorail is easy but extra money. Just choose any road and make your day visiting Odaiba!

Lots to do. From cosplay to car shows. Odaiba has a lot to offer. Amazing view of the seawall and the Rainbow Bridge. The miniature Statue of Liberty and the huge Gungdam. Or spend a day at the beach.

Great place to visit. You can find great view and anything you need to this area.Go diver city to eat great food and shopping, aqua city as well.If you wanna have a view-stay of rainbow city then you shall stay at Nikko hotel or pacific le daiba.

Great view !. Nice view, lot of places to eat and shop ! I did not go there to shop but rather to hang out and enjoy the scenery. There were groups of students having their class trip (?) when I visited the place. ir was fun watching these youngsters in their school uniforms.

Nice View. Very nice view of Tokyo Bay, Rainbow Bridge and central Tokyo skyline from Odaiba beach. So many youngsters especially during summer evening.I took Yurikamome train from Shimbashi Station (Yamanote Line).

Really nice, open area. I visited here a few times when I lived in Tokyo late 2012. I would consider it as a bit of a hidden gem - while many people know about Shibuya or Harajuku this area is not as famous. I really enjoyed it every time I went - it's more open than the crowded streets of the inner city, and there is lots to do.Firstly you can walk across the Rainbow bridge to get there - it offers nice views of Tokyo and the bay area. There are lots of shopping malls with a good selection of high end shops as well as regular high street stores and restaurants. There are sculptures and museums and a ferris wheel and a giant robot - pretty much a fully catered for day out.

Shoppers Delight, particularly in Summer. Odaiba has really developed into a shopper's paradise, with the development of a number of large shopping malls in the area. Aqua City, one of the older shopping malls, has a great beer garden attached to its restaurants on the 5th floor - perfect to enjoy the views of Rainbow Bridge.
Love this Place!. Must visit - Sega Joypolis. This place made me feel like a little kid all over again. You've never tried amusement park like this.

what a good attraction things to see here...... went to odaiba through yurikamone line....the train went through the rainbow bridge....it's quite a windy city but we really love it after being in tokyo with the hot weather during the summer time....took many pictures at the statue of liberty then we went to fuji tv....loved it cause we can see many kinds of fuji tv production. walked further up we can see the gundam!...what a hugh giant gundam.....we were lucky cause could see the gundam moved....then we went to the web toyota...got to get to many cars that were on displayed.....if you go to tokyo this is a MUST visit place to visit......

Something here for everyone. We had seen the giant futuristic ball (Fugi) TV studio across Tokyo bay many times driving back and forth to the airport - but it took visiting family to get us over there and I wish we had gone sooner. Odaiba island is a self contained park, mall, and sight seeing area easily accessible via the Tokyo subway/monorail system. Take the first car in the monorail if you can for the best views through the harbor. Once you arrive the elevator ride to the "big ball" is somewhat overpriced (averages about $8 depending on ages) but does give you incredible 360 views of the city/harbor area. There is a lot of classic japanese kitsch (to scale model of the Statue of Liberty for example!) but great shopping and eating as well. Try the ramen museum on the 5th floor of the aqua building - very reasonably priced and great varieties of ramen all in one place. The only downside - as commented on by other reviewers - is that there is a lot of walking involved and taking the trains (switching etc) can take time getting there. We took the water taxi back to town which was a break from the trains and also provided beautiful views from the water level. Great way to spend a day in Tokyo. And kids will love the Joypolis - a sega inside amusement park. We parked them there for a couple of hours and went upstairs for Korean barabecue - everyone was happy!

Nice relaxing piece of Tokyo. Can stroll around most of the island, lots of shopping, food and activities for kids - huge Gundam, Statue of Liberty, waterbus, amusement arcades and, of course, great views of Tokyo across the water

The Big Island. Lots to do and see, but you have to work for it. Like all Tokyo, everything is spread out, and a lot of walking is involved with lots of train rides from place to place. Best to pick one or two attractions and spend more time there. Coming back another day to enjoy other attractions. If not you will spend most of time walking or riding the train. Don't miss the Statue of Liberty. It's a nice touch for Tokyo.

Amazing!!. I didn't know such a beatifull place before my friend took me there. We arrived Aquacity after we cross Rainbow bridge. Amazing view from Aquacity terrace. Tokyo bay surrounded by many high-rise,bridge, monument around.evening also amazing view with lighting of bridge and buildings.. I really enjoyed, I'll go there again my next japan trip..and u can shopping there bcos there are 2 big shopping mall.

A fantastic place to visit. I really loved Odaiba, even I fail to try the cruise and Then I have to use a monorail to go there. But, it was a really great experience. I can take a picture of a liberty statue there, so I don't have to go to New York City. Then I accidentally found Madame Tussauds Museum, I take a lot of pictures there. But, unfortunately I didn't go to Gundam Museum and take a picture with the giant robot. One more thing, the city view and the bridge was awesome!

Tons of foodies, outlet malls; gundam, Venus fort, tokyo decks 6th floor Hong Kong foodies..attractions galore... Plat horas of foods that opens until 3 or 4 AM. Gonpachi restaurant open until 3 am for yakitory and beers. Okinawa foods open until 4 am small noodle bowls can be had for $5 bks no tax drinks $1Will need more than a day to sample the attractions from ferrous wheels, Gundam Cafe and Venus Fort. There is a free shuttle bus for tired feet that stops in all areas attraction!Rainbow bridge , beach, Statue of Liberty, shop till you drop,Cheers!

Nice days out !!. One day is not enough to spend in this place: Shopping, two large malls are in the place with nice goods, Aqua city and Diver city, Cinema, the huge statue, the garden and water side to spend a nice time, the rainbow bridge & replica of the statue of Liberty with Tokyo tower on the other side make a nice view in the day time and nicer in the night, Madame Tussauds, Lego land, a wide range of restaurants in both malls We had to go there three times to finish what we needed to see.It is a place you can go with your family, friends, or even solo.
excellent Development. This is recent developed area of Tokyo were the Giant Ferry wheel ,National Science museum and shopping malls are located.

Gundam and the Statue of Liberty. A very good place to hang around and sightsee. There is a replica of the Statue of Liberty with the magnificent Rainbow bridge in the background. Its nice to come at sunset and see the transition and lighting of the bridge. This is really a reclaimed land with numerous shops and eating places. It is impossible to miss Gundam.

Great area, but super confusing to navigate. Odaiba has so much to do – Lego Land, Sega world, daikanransha (ferris wheel), the Toyota showroom, ferries, the giant Gundam, the beach, restaurants and shops.... There is even a statue of liberty replica.
It’s easy to get too and you can easily lose a day there. Recommended for a nice day out.

Tokyo waterfront favorite spot. A wonderful series of shopping complexes, hotels, TV station, and restaurants with a must-see man made beach. A good day is needed to tour the whole area, including Divercity, a new shopping complex nearby.
So much to see and do a Tokyo MUST!. From Gundam to the Onsen to the cosplay folks to the beach to all the amazing cool buildings one must visit ODAIBA when in Tokyo.

Artificial.. It was my first time in Japan, and up until visiting Odaiba, I thought all of the neighbourhoods in Tokyo have been very interesting. Some areas may be more commercialized, but it still retained a sense of Japanese authenticity and uniqueness especially since most of the areas are older with history.I thought Odaiba was not very "Japan". I found it very American, actually, due to the large shopping centres AND the shameless replica of the Statue of Liberty. It was also trying to be tropical and resort-y based on the music playing and the design of some buildings. I just thought it was trying too hard to be non-Japan. Having said that, I was only there for a couple of hours and mainly at the shopping centres. My brother also went to the Gundam Museum and The Science and Innovation Museum, and he found those interesting. So if you're a Gundam fan or a scientist or a resort junkie, then Odaiba is the place for you. I would've rather explored other neighbourhoods for my first visit to Tokyo.

Shopping and fun island. This island is filled with shopping malls, restaurants beaches and museums.Is easily reachable with the metro and to get there you cross the famous rainbow bridge.If is not your first time in Tokyo and you wish to spend some time doing something different, this might be the place.

Odiaba. Odiaba is a place to go in the late afternoon to walk around and then eat at a restaurant with a view of the Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo as the sun goes down. There are many restaurants and a lot of shopping.

pretty urban seashore. Nice mall with restaurants and souvenir shops, pretty view from the seashore. You can watch beautiful sunset and school of fish jumping up and down the surface of ocean water. In fact those are all i can remember..........romantic place.

Don't Miss It - Take the Kids~!!. This is a "park" that cannot be described in this small place. All the newest inventions, computers cars, motorcycles, appliances are available for trying. The train goes right to it. Get a day pass for the train - that's cheaper~!! Do not miss this place~!!
Location.. Great location, entertainment, shopping malls, transport options. Easy walking to tourist sights. Clean, safe location.

Lots of entertainment. Odaiba has many tourist spots - Lego Land, Ferris Wheels, the beach, sightseeing ferries, etc. The best way to enjoy Odaiba is using the free shuttle which stops most of the main attractions.Time table for free shuttle bus (sorry Japanese only);http://www.hinomaru.co.jp/metrolink/odaiba/odaiba_map.htmlMost of places in Odaiba opens after 11am (Lego Land opens 10am), so if you are bored in the morning, you can go for a walk along the beach. There is a nice walkway from Daiba station to the beach and you can see the statue of liberty.

Sentosa of Tokyo - Odaiba. Odaiba is an artificial island near Tokyo bay. This is a huge amalgamation of shopping, fun, entertainment ,sight-seeing and amusement. The Yurikamome – a driverless train which makes you enter this area of Tokyo is super impressive. Odaiba has so much to offer, even 1 day might not be enough.Among many intersecting sights here would include the Rainbow bridge, Statute of Liberty, diver city, Toyoto museum,Fuji tower, Panasonic center Tokyo leisure land & Daikanransha Ferris wheel.Plus huge shopping malls esp. Auqacity and many large food courts.Its huge area, much bigger than Sentosa of SIN.

Spacious, calm with real feel.... I had been here along with my wife and her colleagues during the last week of Apr '14. We went there around 5pm on a Sunday. Entry is free. The place is situated with a view of the 'rainbow bridge'. It has a huge mass of water made to look like sea which also makes small waves, with an island in between. The whole place was very big, calm and made us think if the whole place was really man-made because it was so very natural.Fish from the water would occasionally pop out, jump and go back in. Since it also had lots of sand, people played some ball-games, kids built castles in the sand, etc. The sunset made the whole experience even more relaxing.Small boats are lit up in different colours and probably have trips for people to look around. And the bridge is apparently lit up in rainbow colours on specific days. On the day we went, the bridge was lit up only in white.Malls around it were lit up well. 2 malls were inter connected and had reasonably good merchandise. Near the monorail station, a building and it's stairs were lit with multi-coloured lighting which changed along with the background music.At around 7.30 in the evening, cool breeze started blowing and many of us wore some jackets to keep ourselves warm.A must see place. Preferred to visit after 4pm for stay till 8pm or so. If it is for a couple looking for loneliness, visit on a weekday.

Go !!. Amazing afternoon we had there.. its an artificial island (direct line from shimbashi station) lovely malls.. took picture with the statue of liberty ( yes they have a smaller replica) and with a gigantic Gundam robot .. at night Fuji TV building is great , there is also a Ferris wheel but it was too cold for that. GO see venus fort its like being in Italy plus they have a super cool old automobiles museums and I think you can even try new models .. there is also hot water baths and museum of technology and innovation , noodles tasting etc.... just go see their website and choose for yourself you will spend a lovely evening ! and eat in the aquacity mall coz the restos are river view :)

Nice Place to go around. You need a day to finish the whole area, lots of things to see for each member of the family, for the automobile enthusiasts check out the Toyota Museum lots of vintage cars you've never seen before. At night you can view the Rainbow Bridge

Very relaxing compared to downtown. I like the morning walks going to the station. The place is so quiet and you see a lot of scenery. It feels so different compared to downtown tokyo like shibuya and shinjuku. There are a lot of attractions to do here as well. Definitely a good place to stay. The downside is, i think the metro going in and out of Odaiba is a bit expensive

A lot to see and do in the area.. Easily accessed by train, the Odaiba area offers something for everyone. Huge shopping malls with plenty of places to shop and eat, the giant Ferris wheel which offers great views of the area and over Tokyo Bay while doing a circuit, a Toyota interactive car show room to keep the menfolk interested while the women go shopping in the malls, a short walk to the Joypolis where you can play games to your heart's content, some interesting building architecture and a giant statue of Gundam. Decks Tokyo Beach has a Legoland and a Madam Tussauds, great for kids. Don't go too early, as the shops don't open until 11am. It would be a great place to see at night when the Rainbow Bridge and Ferris wheel are illuminated.

Man made island made for entertainment.. This was probably my favorite location in Tokyo. Wide open spaces, great view of Tokyo over the harbor, lots of very cool shops to see, giant Ferris wheel, Fuji TV building at night was really cool to watch the lights show. My kids loved the lighted stairs at night. Statue of liberty. I recommend to come in the evening to see the sunset behind Tokyo and then see all the bright light at night from the Ferris wheel. You can arrive here by a river cruise from Asakusa and avoid the rush hour of Tokyo metro.

An evening of lights. An area that is different from the rest of Tokyo, clearly was built from a blank canvas. Spacious walkways and visually interesting buildings including the Gundam statue. The whole area is new looking. A night the place is lit up including night cherry blossom trees ( from the lights). There are a number of shopping malls. We arrived late in the evening and had dinner inside Diver City. Afterwards we walked outside to see the Gundam statue all lit up.The monorail trip to Odaiba was the highlight. It starts at Shimbashi passing the skyscrapers in the area and continues above ground the whole time. Lovely views of Tokyo Bay and it goes across the Rainbow bridge. An easy way to see Tokyo sitting down! The train ride is not cheap but worth a ride.

Cool place to visit across the bay. definitely take the ferry across rather than the monorail, it can be accessed from the Hama Rikyu Gardens. The ferry takes approximately 10-15 minutes and you get some great views. Odaiba is very "futuristic" and many things can be found to do including seeing the Tokyo Statue of Liberty

good for a short visit and shopping. It is the right place for shopping and also to see the Japan technology such as bridges, high rise buildings and malls. It is better to go at weekdays since malls are over crowded at weekends.

Best Part of Tokyo. This has to be one of my favorite parts of Tokyo. Shopping, restaurants, arcade games and the best views any where. We had to make a second trip because we enjoyed it so much the first time.

Fun place for first time visiters. Its a great new place for visitors to check out. With an abundance of shopping centers and famous landmark within very close proximity of each other. Its easy to spend a whole day here. Although a little far from the main area of Tokyo. Taking the Monorail will get you across the beautiful rainbow bridge.
The wind is strong but access is good.. You can go to Odaiba with a train which directly goes there, The sceneries from the windows of train "Yuricamome" is very good.

Shop till you drop. If the high end stores of Ginza aren't your thing and the idea of being in two huge malls is.. This is the place for you.
I spent a whole day here and bought most of my clothes at great prices. Many of the stores offer tax refunds.
This place is a must.

Nice place to hang around. It's a good place for hang around, they have Sega joypolis, Gundam big statue which can move his head :) , Liberty statue, also its park is a nice track for jogging, you also might see couple walking around, kids running over there. Lovely though.
I recommend it.

Great place to see Tokyo View with Rainbow bridge as a background. nice place to walk around and enjoy the view of Tokyo in different perspective
enjoying rainbow bridge view at night also nice .. while sitting at one of the coffee shop
if you're lucky you'll see a wedding reception at one of the mall there ...

Night view is fabulous.. It's a very modern and vital busiest quarter.
This district is just like a Gangman- in Seoul.
Very impressive site, but there's nothing to do, except shopping.
There are many nice shopping malls here, and foods are very nice.
Keep in mind you must go there at the night.

Soulless - but with Kit-Kats. We've just returned from this monolith that was kind of like visiting a dystopian future.Huge but kind of sad. Heaps of shopping places so a great place to find big brand stores all in one area.If you're keen to find Kit-Kats then the duty free shop in Aqua City has wasabi, strawberry cheesecake, rum and raisin and green tea and cherry blossom. The Daiso nearby has a couple of other flavours too (the more common ones) which make for great souvineers.

Another side of Tokyo, must visit !. I stayed at this area on my first trip to Tokyo in June 2013, after get recommendation, surfed a lot, and turned out to be awesome experiences. It's a new modern Tokyo which suit family travellers, lots to see and experience. Train station crossed the Rainbow Bridge gracefully, beautiful sceneries, LEGOLAND, Madame Tussaud, 4 shopping malls in walking distance, Toyota Mega Web, the giant Ferris, Onsen, Museums. Spacious hotel rooms, I used it at my base since travelling to Disney Resort only takes 30 minutes. I stayed there 9 nights and my kids love it.

Change of pace in Tokyo. Odaiba on a weekday is quiiiiiet! Okay, almost dead, actually. BUT! All this space to yourself makes a nice change of pace, and I would recommend it as a place to enjoy yourself away from the crowds. Weekends are busy though. There are quite a few things to do, indoors and out, so allow 4 hours at least. We enjoyed the view over the port (from the viewing deck and especially from the giant ferris wheel), Toyota Mega Web showroom, a look at the bizarre world of Venus Fort mall, and a stroll in the garden outside. Of course, there is lots and lots more to do beyond this, but we just ran out of time. Great for families, friends, or couples.

Good place to shop. Odaiba is a good place to shop and eat!! Not very far from central Tokyo and easy to get to. Weekends can be packed but worth going!! If you get lost just ask any Japanese guys because Odaiba is a famous place and even the Japanese young people go to this place.

A Bit of Everything. Odaiba is a great place to spend half a day or so and here are three reasons why: 1) You get a great view of Tokyo (The Rainbow Bridge and the skyline). 2) The architecture present on the island has a very futuristic feel to it (Fuji TV building and Tokyo Big Sight). 3) There is life-size Gundam suit. Bonus: There was a trick art museum, which was a lot of fun.

Need to do some shopping? This is the place.. Odaiba is home to the iconic Fuji TV building and shopping! There are two malls, the older Aqua City and the newer Diver City. Diver City has 6 floors of stores to chose from ranging from a 100yen shop to Burberry with everything in between. And for those of you with a craving for a good fish taco, visit the Mexican Restaurant on the 7th floor and you won't be disappointed.

Awesome Gundam statue, not too much else. The Gundam statue was definitely the high point. You can safely skip the Historical Garage, Fuji TV station, and Italian-style fountain shopping area. The food was nothing to write home about. One thing I will say about Odaiba - it's expansive and topographically interesting (for an artificial island). We spent maybe 3 hours total there, spread out among all of the 4 attractions mentioned.
Medium to High End. After the seeing the prices in the malls of Nagoya I was presently surprised. I could actually afford to buy something in this mall. There is a cash exchange located downstairs.

The modern tokyo with panoramic view of Tokyo itself. Besides having series of good-value international chain hotel with spacious rooms, Odaiba offers you a great view of Tokyo CBD and shopping centres within your reach. The only drawback is the location since you must put aside budget for the Odaiba Line train cost which is not cheap compared to other lines and its not covered by the JR Rail Pass.

Food, Shopping, Entertainment. The Odaiba is a popular shopping and entertainment hub on the Tokyo Bay island. Great place to spend some leisure time at. What I loved about the place is the clear demarcation of pedestrian walk strips and vehicles pathways. The place is amazing neat and well-maintained offering a nice ocean view. I had taken my wife to the Odaiba on almost three occasions and we had a great time. The Fuji TV building and the Aqua City were interesting places. Though I personally like the Aqua City better. The 13 screen multiplex offers a great time. We had visited the Ramen theme food park and tried out a variety of Ramens from all over Japan. Truly a great experience.
Beautiful place. Love this beautiful place... very peaceful and beautiful especially in the evening. Don't miss Gundam Centre here for great selection of Gundam

Quiet and spacious. Bought the day pass for the elevated train that takes you around the various attractions on this man-made island. There’s a little bit of everything for everyone here. A couple of malls, cinemas, onsen, Ferris wheel, giant gundam and a good range of eateries. Unfortunately, the Toyota Mega Web was closed for maintenance. Lunch at the Decks with a view of the Rainbow Bridge is great. For those with a thing for buildings, the Fuji TV Building is quite spectacular too.One can chose to spend a whole day or probably half a day is good to get away from the bustle of downtown Tokyo since Odaiba is quiet and spacious although I found it to be ultimately a little soulless.

a great shopping destination. Set aside a good full day if you plan on some serious shopping here! Anything is available, from Toys R Us to clothing, plus museums and mid-range restaurants - a favorite weekend destination for normal japanese families. Interesting.

A romantic Place in Tokyo. Odaiba is a beautiful place to spend time during the eveing. A calm place away from City center. The beautiful view of the rainbow bridge, Glowing Tokyo Tower, Cool breez form coming from the sea, a replica of Statue of Liberty, what else you want from a place. Sit by the side and enjoy the view. Shop at the malls all a walk away. A perfect and must go place in Tokyo. If lucky, try to get a ride of Himiko Boat as well. Eat at resutrants which have amazing view overlooking the Rainbow Bridge. For kids or for some grownup kids, the Gian Gundhum Show is very entertaining. A good place for couples as well. Sit on the benches near the water of take a walk.

Gotta see the Giant Gundham. My friend and I went here for my last site seeing trip in Japan. We went just to see the life size Gundham. It's pretty cool I think it's more for kids but I liked it. It comes to life in the evening which was pretty cool. Lots of cool shopping too.

Away from city centre. Clean and less traffic. Free shuttle bus around town. Lots of shopping malls to visit with attractions and interesting places. Chill at Odaiba pier where you can see futuristic Hotluna or Himiko boat berthing while you sip 100yen soda. Or walk up the pier to Statue of Liberty. It's fun!

Could not experience it all. We decided to go to Odaiba in some spare time we had. The trip in the monorail is nice crossing the water, but Odaiba was a little bit disappoining, though I believe that is due to our late arrival (few things were open) and its huge dimensions. There are attractions here that I would have liked to experience, like the Oedo Onsen Monogatari or the Museum of Maritime Science. This that I did: Venus Fort, which is a mall of Venetian style, nice for some time; Toyota Mega Web is an exhibition of cars, pretty interesting; the copy of the Statue of Liberty, nice for some snapshots; Leisureland, simply without words, a huge complex of all kind of videogames and machines, so typical in Japan. I would not choose Odaiba for a first trip to Japan, but it could be a nice secondary option for further visits to Japan.

A great place to relax in Tokyo!. Odaiba is a great place to escape from the busy Tokyo. We took the boat cruise from Asakusa pier to Odaiba in the afternoon and it was a great experience indeed where we can see some seagulls flying over the boat. Reached Aquacity in about 1 hour and shop at Diver's City where we can take pictures of the life-size Gundam figure in front of the mall during sunset. There are many places for food (including a St Marc Cafe branch) and drinking water is free for public at the food court. Didn't managed to walk to Fort Venus due to timing, but the 2 malls are sufficient enough to spend the evening. A pleasant walk to view the Rainbow Bridge and Statue of Liberty after dark accompany by Christmas songs playing from the open air cafe is unforgettable.

Man made Island of fun!. Odiaba is the place to go for a full day of fun. Whether soaking in the hot springs of Oedo Onsen Monogatari, shopping at multiple amazing shopping centers such as Aqua City or touring the world famous Fuji TV station, there is no end of things to do. Definitely dedicate a full day or two to really explore with wonderful place.

Great for an afternoon. The train to Odaiba is a great experience, at one pointing seeming to curl around into a arc as you go across the water. We visited early one morning and the weather was pleasantly warm. Odaiba is full of little treats and provides a bit of peace and quiet from central Tokyo. There's the usual shops of course (including a West Coast Choppers branch!), the 'mini' Statue of Liberty, and so on. The Gundam statue is quite impressive, and makes for some great photos. My favourite has to be the Sega Joypolis. You can buy a ticket to cover all rides, which is what we did. At first it's a little overwhelming if you're not exactly fluent in Japanese, but it's a great experience with plenty to see and do.

Great for shopping and other attractions!. There are many sales and outlet stores that you can visit here. There are also tons of attractions and things to do here. You will never get bored in Odaiba because everywhere you go will have something. I suggest you go early in the day because we got here at 2pm and we did not have enough time to go around as much and we ended up rushing in the end.

Sunset over Tokyo. Odaiba has several things to see: from traveling there on a fully automatic Yurikamome train (note: it's not covered by subway and JR passes) to Madame Tussaud's museum and ocean seaside. But the best for me was a view of a sunset over Tokyo when you see it from Odaiba island. If you like walking, go back and cross Rainbow Bridge on foot to see Tokyo bay.

Shopping and sightseeing. There are heaps of malls and also lots to see. I enjoyed going up the Fuji Building and the views of Rainbow bridge and Tokyo were great, particularly when it gets darks and the city lights up. A great place to spend an afternoon and evening!

The future is now. We were on a JTB / Sunrise Tour. The Statue of Liberty was interesting... New York felt so close. There was a big mall that had lots of stores with friendly and helpful employees. There was also a area with a big robot outfront - the size of the two story building. The main building looks like something from the future. Great views of the bay and downtown Tokyo.
Malls with different shops. There is a lot of different shops and arcades. Not too crowded on a Saturday. Nice promenades. I prefer this over the malls at Shibuya.

Great place to shop and to visit. Plenty shopping malls with outlet available in Odaiba. Not to miss the nice view of rainbow bridge, statue of liberty and also 1:1 ratio of Gundam right infront the Diver City mall. Joypolis is available at the Decks mall and you gonna spend the whole afternoon there if you're a gamer! Regret as dint spare more time to be in Odaiba!

Odaiba - worth visiting, plenty to do. This is my second visit to Odaiba. ITi s an interesting place with many shopping malls. There are a few ways of getting there: Waterboat from Asakusa, Rinkai JR line or the monorail at Shinagawa, pick your choice. Obviously the price of the ticket can be different.There is a full size gundnam robot outside Divercity shopping mall. There a replica of statue of liberty with the suspended bridge as the back drop. We took the ferries wheel in the evening and had a nice view of the skyline of tokyo in the night. Worth, if you are not afraid of heights.We also spent time at VenueFort, a fun place where there was a pet cafe where people bring their pets in.There is also a Toyota exhibition centre and many to see. In summary, there is so much to do at Odaiba and a day is not enough if you wish to visit all the malls. It is good family fun for a day.
Must See Attraction of Tokyo. Plan a full day for this place and you won't regret it. Lot of photographs to be taken, lot many joints to eat and a lot many places to shop at.

A gem by the bay. There is enough at Odaiba to keep you occupied throughout the day. There is something for every taste. An eveining ride on Yurikamome train gives the wonderful view of Rainbow Bridge, specially when it goes in a loop. We spent only an evening here, thinking to fill time on our first evening in Tokyo, and feel we shortchanged ourselves. Next time we will allot more time to Odaiba.

Odaiba. This is a cool place to shop and check out the new waterfront development. It has some cool places for the sightsee-ers, including Rainbow Bridge, a replica Statue of Liberty, the massive Gundam robot, contemporary architecture and landscaping. The shopping is awesome so bring your credit card!

Enjoying the place. The place is totally different from Tokyo. Everything is there already. Dont buy 1day ticket. You can just walk through the man made island to explore every inch of place. Ohhh. This is not include shopping street .
nice location. i love here . its business area but in the same time u can have such a good time with family or couples
Fun little area. Odaiba is a fun, charming man-made island in Tokyo. It's fun, there's a lot of things to do and see, and there's quite a few shopping complexes.

Lots to see and do on Odaiba Island. Easy to get to - just transfer onto the Yurikamome line at Shimbashi or Shiodome. Lots to see and do - we loved Mirikan (the national museum of emerging sciences and technology) where we saw Asimo; Diver City (with its giant robot out the front of the shopping centre) was worth a visit; the shopping centres (Decks etc) fronting onto the bay were worth visiting at night for great views of Rainbow Bridge... and the driverless train itself (to get to Odaiba Island) is pretty cool!

Beautiful, futuristic area! Worth visiting.. My family visited this area primarily to attend a wedding at a hotel. The hotel (Nikko Hotel) and the area is very futuristic and beautiful. It offers ocean (at Bay), many shops and restaurants. You can also see Tokyo's beautiful night view across from the bay. If you have a chance, it worths visiting.

Brilliant Odaiba!. Love this modern, fun and exciting part of Tokyo. Took the high- level railway to get here. What a great experience! The Gundam robot is the highlight of my visit as I grew up watching Daimos and Voltes V too!

Great day out. I was stoked that I could fit this into my time in Tokyo - such a relaxing day. There's a massive variety of shopping and tonnes of things to do. All with fabulous views over Tokyo bay. A great place to walk around and spontaneously decide when you see something that you might like to check it out.

If you have good weather, a nice place for stroll. Open spaces, some quirky interesting shops. There some museums that could be worth a visit. Acceees is pretty gppd via both subway and the Yurikamome elevated train line which provides quite a futuristic feel for the trip from Shinbashi between the tower blocks and over the long bride to Odaiba.

So much to do and something for everyone. Absolutely loved this area. Felt very safe walking around though the shops close around 8pm.There are numerous malls with shops for every interest. One had a small video game amusement section that you had to pay to get in. Did not have the time for it but it looked very interesting.Large food court in one of them with just about all types of foods. Helps when everyone wants to eat something different. My family could have spent half a day there. Would definitely go again.JR train station is right there. Beautiful view of the Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo Bay.

Excellent family fun. There are lots of interesting places to see here. We shopped, went on the ferris wheel, wandered around the harbour, played in the water mist pus more. You could spend all day here, we didn't get there to early evening and stayed for about 5 hours. Loved it.

No words to describe. This place has many, various buidling. Also, within each building has variety kinds of goods. Besides buying stuff, we can have activities such as going to musuem and playing games. Last but not least, the sights is very impressive.

Something for the whole family. We are into seeing new architecture, shopping and current media. Odaiba had it all. I was recommended to start at Tokyo's Big Site (the upside down pyramids) There were a number of events happening, the largest draw was something to do with manga. It was quite a spectacle to see all the young girls dressed up and waiting in line for the new books. We then spent quite a bit of time in Toyotas' Megaweb, where you can see models only available in Japan and do some simulation driving. On our walk to Megaweb we encountered a number of "cosplay" taking photos on the shores. We then had lunch in Laforet while checking out various fashion clothing. Walking further we encountered a hugh Gundum model. Then we saw (but were too late to get into) the Fuji TV building. If we had more time we would have spent more time in a Sega entertainment complex. The kids would have stayed there all day but the adults had enough.

Lots to see within walking distance!. We headed over to Odaiba after seeing the Imperial Palace in the morning and having a lunch at the Tokyo Railway station.There are lots of interesting places to see, things to do and shopping! Our group of friends split up for 4 hours in order to all see what we wanted.Fuji Tv studio, Decks, Venus Fort, Aqau City, Diver City, Onsen museum. And within all those have many small things to see and do.We still hadnt finished it all, and had to rush by the end.If you only had a few days in Tokyo, you could perhaps give it a miss, but as this was our second time, we went for a look, and I am glad we did. Takoyaki museum, Wax museum, Legoland discovery centre, huge 1:1 gundam front statue, fake stastue of liberty, toyota exploration zone. The onsen museum we went in the evening, it was very unexpected inside and amazing!

Huge shopping area. Visited the Odaiba area on a sunday, very crowded everywhere in malls and restaurants. The area offers lot of shopping and amusement for fhe whole family. The seaside walk is nice with an overlook of Tokyo bay with its harbours, bridges and the city skyline.

Relax & enjoy. I usually go to indoor hot springs nearby for all day and thenhead out during dinner time to Odaiba. It’s very gorgeous at night with all the lightings. There are so much shopping to do and resturants to eat. Also during Christmas time, there are some lighted decorations that you can take pictures with and such.
