Lots to do. The museum that holds Asimo is in Odaiba. The area itself is very nice with a nice stroll along the sea. The statue of liberty is also here. Lots of malls with lots of shops in the area. Can spend a good day in this area.

Fun Day. We spent the day at Odaiba and really enjoyed it. The museum of innovation and emerging technology has some really interesting exhibitions including the famous ASIMO robot. We also went to Legoland Discovery Centre which the kids loved. We went on a weekday out of the Japanese holiday season and neither were crowded at all.

Odaiba- One stop destination for shopping,food,games and landscape. Firstly Reaching Odaiba with its mono rail ride is worth visiting as sides of the rail line you can see landscapes,Buildings. Odiaba also called as man made island got numerous stores from designer to discount ones and sega got its own complex with fun filled gamings which gives you anime feel.Rainbow bridge in the back ground will give you the feel of America (watch out for the statue of liberty statue near by).You need to get down at the daiba station for easy access to everything or you need to get down at odaiba and walk for some distance.There is a multiplex with lots of screens and eveyr now and then promotional events happen including the summer carnival.

Amazing Skyline Views!. This man made island is only accessible via Shinagawa station and it does take about 20 minutes to actually get to but it is 100% worth the trip, dont get a taxi! Its basically just an entertainment and shopping district but theres some good eats to be had! Theres a shopping centre on the island which houses a very decent variety of eateries and restaurants. It also has panoramic views of riverside Tokyo and theres tonnes of aircraft everywhere flying into Haneda, its like stepping back and just seeing the urban metropolis all in one view, its truly amazing, it proves you dont need a lot of greenery to have an incredible ecosystem. I would go just for the view but good for shopping and eating, make time for it!
shopping & onsen. Lots to see and do! Due to rain, we were forced indoors for the afternoon. Spent it at Oedo Onsen Monogatari! Perfect rainy day spot.
modern. Lovely views of Tokyo and specially Rainbow Bridge, malls and remarkable buildngs, and ultramodern metro station. Ia a artificial island.
Not cheap place..... Very interesting place to visit. It is a mall - the train ride to Odaiba pays the price of the visit. You should go by train... don~t even think about going by taxe.

Perfect stay area for family travellers with kids. We choose this area for our first trip to Tokyo and its perfectly our imaginations. Fresh and beautiful scenery. Nice malls. Train station is walking doorsteps. We miss our hotel shuttle bus from DisneySea and take taxi to Diver City. Cost JPY 4820 for 25 minutes drive. Airport Limousine fom Narita takes about 65 minutes and cost JPY 2700 (Adult).

Peaceful. i've been to Odaiba twice and i just like being there. it's away from the mainland and it somehow has a very calm, peaceful and slow pace feel compare to heart of Tokyo. You take a monorail to Odaiba and there's so many interesting sights to see during the ride.Odaiba is like a huge funland. There's ferris wheel, a big Toyota megashow ground, shopping mall and lots of restaurants and good food to choose from. You can spot one of the iconic Fuji TV "ball" and at night you get a beautiful sight of the Rainbow bridge (which actually its just a normal bridge lighted up at night to make it look like a rainbow).if you had been in Tokyo for a few days and want to get to a slower pace ground, try Odaiba

Theres a lot going on. If you go at the right moment, theres events like beer fest, anime fest, food fest. The Mall is great with all the new brands. You can go to any mall around and the food is awsome. The only thing about odaiba is that its a little far from the center of Tokyo so you might need like half a day or a full day for your visit. The only beach in Tokyo (dont swim in them tho!) , and a small island you can walk and visit. BIG GANDAM infront of DiverCity (Mall).

Great for a weekend outing. There are 4 big malls with many options to eat. The sea front near the boat jetty offers some fantastic views of the Tokyo skyline and Rainbow Bridge. There is also a small version of the statute of liberty, and the area near that is quite beautiful to walk around during dusk. Venus mall has the car showroom by Toyota and has a lot of old vintage cars. There is lots of things to do for kids including the gundam. The trickster museum is also worth a visit.

Touristy. Went to visit Odaiba to see the transport museum which Toyota has there. Many fine examples of old cars and good gift shop. Otherwise just spent some time in the shops in one of the malls. Very Americanised I feel.

A Little Sterile. Odaiba is a man-made island with lots of high rises, shopping malls, and a few museums. Overall I found it a bit sterile. It's worth going to if you want to see the museums, but it seems pretty barren when you are walking through it. However, there are some pretty good views of Tokyo and the Rainbow Bridge from the beach and high rise buildings.
Fabulous island!. Odaiba offers so many different things its hard to name just one. From great malls to interesting museums to a wonderful hot springs resort, its all here for a fun day.

Odaiba, Tokyo is one of the best scenic waterfront area in the world. Odaiba, Tokyo is considered to be one of scenic beautiful waterfront area in the world. It is truly magnificent. For going to Odaiba, you have to first reach Shinbashi station (one of the major subway station in Tokyo). From there you have to catch new Yurikamome line. This railway line is not included in one day unlimited Tokyo train travel pass. You are required to purchase fresh ticket to board this train. This train is in elevated track and journey through this train is spectacular, particularly while passing through Rainbow Bridge. The New Transit Yurikamome line train is fully automated, that is there is no driver and it uses tyres within a track, rather than the steel wheels of train. The Rainbow Bridge is a suspension bridge over the Tokyo Port, located on the northernmost part of Tokyo Bay, connecting the Shibaura Wharf and the new waterfront development area, known as Odaiba, Tokyo. Odaiba is sometimes also referred to as Daiba and this becomes a little confusing, but they actually mean slightly different things. Odaiba is not a formal name, but normally refers to the whole of the artificial island in Tokyo Bay, which is joined to the main land by the famous Rainbow Bridge.There is sitting area where you can have spectacular view of waterfront, bay area and Rainbow Bridge. This area is truly picturesque and its beauty is unbelievable. The day I visited, it was clear sky and enjoyed like anything. You can spend time as much as you can. There is one replica of “Statue of Liberty”. “Aqua City” shopping and entertainment complex is adjacent to this. Half a day is essential to explore the Odaiba area thoroughly. Waterfront, Tokyo Bay, Rainbow Bridge, Skyscrapers, shopping and entertainment complex make the Odaiba area is truly marvelous. I will never forget this top class waterfront area in Tokyo. People visiting Tokyo must visit Odaiba area without any fail. Odaiba observation desk, museums, art galleries, Fuji TV studios, gardens and parks, amusement parks make this area truly majestic.
A marvelous area to walk and sightsee. Architectural marvels to see and lots to do. Walking over the Rainbow Bridge was a highlightTrain connectivity is a little difficult

Gandam and Rainbow bridge. This place has good photo shoot spots, for Gandam robot fans and for nature lovers the Rainbow bridge beside the beach. Nice relaxing feeling when we went here. Its a modern place which is recommended for those with more time in Tokyo, since there are other bettter place to visit than this.
loved Odaiba. So clean and people were so friendly.Beautiful waterside area with many shops, Toyota Web Mega showroom, The huge Wheel, Pallette Town, Venus Fort shopping area. Fantastic

Man made island. Being man made, Odaiba is well set up for you to walk around without having to worry about traffic and crossing the busy roads of Tokyo - it's all seaside parks and raised pedestrian walkways. There are some very nice hotels to stay in, lots of malls to shop at, and some interesting attractions to visit too. And I haven't even mentioned the fantastic views of Tokyo city yet either. Hop on the Yurikamome line at Shimbashi and try to get a front seat in the driverless train over the Rainbow Bridge to Odaiba. And remember to stop off and say konichiwa to ASIMO at Miraikan

A lovely place to visit!. If you are looking for a change or want to have a glimpse of nature but dont want to travel far, Odaiba is the place. The place is beautiful in the evenings and coloerful in the nights, The places like the Odaiba bridge, Statue of Liberty and the beach is worth seeing. We watched the bridge from sunset till it became dark. That way we could enjoy the lightings of the bridge, Overall its a fine place for a hangout.

Lots of malls and great attractions. Odaiba island has several malls and attractions on it. Most of the malls are just that, malls. So not much there to talk about. The one in Palette Town is European themed on the second floor, so if feels like you're walking through small Villa in the evening. Other than that, it's a mall. The island is large, so expect to walk quite a bit. Keep an eye out for the large robot and Statue of Libery!The Fuji TV building has an observation deck, but it is closed on Mondays, the day we were there. I hear it's cool.We enjoyed Palette Town the most. Besides the mall, there is the Toyota Mega Web building and the ferris wheel. The Toyota attraction is like a large interactive showroom. There is a go-kart area for kids, in which they must assemble parts of the kart prior to riding! It was so neat and educational! That is why they are better than we are in my opinion. American kids would balk at the idea of having to 'work' before having fun. Also available is a test drive area for new Toyota models. You must have a Japanese or International Driver's License, however. The ferris wheel has climate controlled cars and offers fantastic views of the city and bay.To get to the island by rail, make your way to the Shimbashi station. From there transfer to the Yurikamone L-line, which will take you over the Rainbow Bridge and will make a couple of stops on the island. Station workers are very attentive and can help you decide where to go or get off.

Modern and a lot of variety to spend one day. There are very different places to visit: Shopping malls, museums, amusement park. It is a bit westernized so that the japaneese touch is lost, but it is an interesting place to go with the kids.

Future town, but starting to lose it's gloss.. More for couples, I went here with a friend, during the week, and it was dead.. Maybe also weekends is a more lively time. Still I do have a very nice memory going there as a couple, the town is impressive if it's your first time in Tokyo, for novice eyes.

A nice and beautiful place. This is a wonderful place. It is a man-made island but nevertheless spectacular. There are many attractions here such as the Ferris Wheel and Fuji TV building and not forgetting "Gundam" (giant robot). Before reaching Odaiba, we will pass the Rainbow bridge which is very spectacular. There is also a replica of the Statue of Liberty. There are many departmental stores here. For those who love shopping, this is the place to go.The Gundam is placed outside Divercity, one of the departmental store. At a fixed hour (think it is at 12pm, 3pm and 5pm) the Gundam will moves its head. It is a nice experience to see man's creation!To go to Odaiba, from Tokyo station, take JR Yamanote line (green line) to Shimbashi (2 stops). In Shimbashi, take Yurikamome line to Daiba. The cost of the ride (single) is JPY310. The day pass costs JPY800. However, I don't think it is necessary to purchase a day pass. Try to sit in the front of the train and enjoy the spectacular view during the 15 min ride.
great. modern with a lot of stuff!! not too much to see, but a great place to spend half a day or so!lots of veg options!

Views and more shopping!. It wouldn't be Tokyo without yet more shopping centers and amusement outlets! Built on a reclaimed land site, the monstrous ferris wheel is what tourists (and Japanese!) seek out. Adults ¥900, children ¥700 for a coloured carriage of which there are 60. (You cannot choose your carriage colour!) There are only 4 clear carriages with views from under your feet, but the wait is usually 20 minutes plus. Ride is about 16 minutes with spectacular views over shipping areas and Tokyo. (I still prefer Tokyo Tower or the new Tokyo Sky Tree for better views over central Tokyo.) In the area there's lots of walking through open areas to get to more shopping centers, but there seem to be fewer people out this way, mainly because the monorail seems to be the quickest way to get there and it's all built slightly out of town. Rainbow Bridge is an attraction in its own right, with rainbow colors lighting up the bridge at night. (Unfortunately, not all colors, nor all parts of the bridge were working the night we were there!)

2st century architecture.. Odaiba is an artificial island in Tokyo Bay. You get there on a rubber tyred metro train with spectacular views of and from the Rainbow Bridge. The island is full of quirky modern buildings, malls, and a small amusement park.

Lots of shops but nothing amazing. I spent about 7 hours here in March. From reading all the reviews I had high expectations. Its mainly shopping centres. I didnt really find anything that stood out compared to whats available in Tokyo.

A lot of places to visit. Get off Odaiba station and you'll find the ferris wheel where you may see Tokyo city area, including the attractions in Odaiba. Cost is 900 yes for the normal carriage. From there, you'll find a big Toyota showroom, Venus mall (with Tokyo' version of Las Vegas Venetian hotel setting). Then walk again and see the big gundam (robot) display outside another mall. On the 3rd level of that mall is a passage going to the train station. It is a bit of a long walk but you'll hardly notice as you'll see the amazing view of the rainbow bridge and Tokyo's mini version of the Statue of Liberty.

Adds Diversity to Trip. We're not the kind of travelers that need to check off a list of must-see attractions, and we've come to enjoy the smaller experiences and squeezing less in a day. So Odaiba wasn't part of a list, but one of our Japanese friends wanted to take us there. After busy train stations, bustling streets, and bright lights, it's a neat break in the big city routine. If you go on a sunny day, the views across the water are excellent, as is the train ride out and over the bridge. The architecture of the Fuji TV building and it's associated observation tour is pretty remarkable, and wandering through the areas were relaxed and uncrowded on a mid-week spring day. We had a picnic lunch by a sandy shore straight across from the skyline of Tokyo, before strolling the area. There's plenty to see there, but don't expect traditional Japan in any way, shape, or form. That doesn't mean it's not a terrific visit and if you have a few days in Tokyo, I would mix it into one of your days to experience more of the contrasts of a city you could explore for years and still not see it all.

Odaiba, Futuristic, Very Cool and Amazing. Our trip started from Narita International. We each bought a 2 day open metro pass and a round trip Keisei Skyliner ticket to get us to Tokyo and back (highly recommended). We had to get a separate pilotless monorail from Shimbashi to get to Odaiba, but the ride itself was pretty spectacular. The views of the city, Rainbow Bridge and the city skyline is all very impressive. Once in Odiaba, we went to Gundam Front where a 1:1 (real life size) replica of Gundam Wing stands in front of the Diver City Mall. If you are a fan of the animated show, you will appreciate the craftsmanship and detail that went into building this life size model. The mall itself is one of the best in Asia with the biggest food court I've seen in a long time. Within a short walking distance is the Science and Technology center where Osimo the Honda robot makes his appearance; agian, this center is so technologically advance and awe inspiring that mere words cannot fully capture the experience we had. I wish we could have stayed there a week. There is so much to see and do, we merely scratched the surface.

Pretty scenery of Tokyo Bay. Great location to view Rainbow Bridge. The Tokyo Bay tours by boat are also a really wonderful way to get up close to Rainbow Bridge & to view the pretty scenery of Tokyo Bay!

A large man-made island beside Tokyo Bay. I did not have any idea what Odaiba was before I went.Actually my friends (actually co-workers) here in Japan told me to go and visit the place. Going to Odaiba is not that hard if you are in Tokyo.There are three convenient ways on getting there.First is by Yurikamome Line (which is an automated,driver-less train that stops at Odaiba Station),by Rinkai Line (stops at Tokyo Teleport Station), and last is by Tokyo Water Bus (a boat stops at Odaiba Seaside Park). I found this website (below) helpful so please check this out for details on how to get there. ( http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e3008.html )One of the reason why I went to Odaiba was the huge Gundam Statue right infront of Tokyo Diver City Plaza. So after getting off (in my case) at Odaiba Station of Yurikamome Line,you have to walk at least 5 minutes before you see the Gundam Statue. The Odaiba Station was not the complicated so you can just refer to the signs (which is written both in Japanese,Korean,English,and I think I saw Chinese characters) of the place that you want to go. The statue of Gundam indeed was very impressive. There you can see lot of people taking pictures. There are this so called Gundam Front Tokyo besides the statue where you can buy Gundam stuffs.In Odaiba you can also see the replica of Statue of Liberty,the Fuji Television building, the Daikanransha (one of the largest Ferris Wheel in the world,Rainbow Bridge,etc.If you want to go to Odaiba just for sightseeing then I think this place is suitable. This place is also ideal for shopping and dining.I heard (although I haven't tried/seen it) that there are good restaurants (particularly Sushi restaurants) inside the Aqua City Odaiba and Diver City Plaza.Downside is,the prices here is quite high.Odaiba all in all is entertaining.Though the place is still under development but I'm sure the place will become one of Tokyo's best attraction.

Japan 2013. The Otaku in me is what made me visit Odaiba. I knew the life-size Gundam was there. Who knew there'd be a cafe with themed food!? Visited the outside of Fuji Television for Digimon reasons, but is still an awesome building.

Well worth the trip.. We actually went here twice. The first trip was just to see a real-life Toyota 2000GT (yes, I am a petrol head) at MegaWeb. That was actually a bit of a disappointment because of the way they have it displayed, in amongst other cars and trucks in what looks like an underground, badly-lit car park. Put it on proper display guys!!Anyway, when we saw what else is in the Odaiba area we made another trip back. Travel either by the fully automated Yurikamome Line (excellent views of the Rainbow Bridge, Tokyo Bay and Tokyo Skyline, or travel by WaterBus (also excellent views and you can also WaterBus up the SumidaGawa to Asakusa from Odaiba).For something really different - walk across the Rainbow Bridge. Approx 1 kilometre long and more excellent views of Tokyo Bay and skyline! At Odaiba there is some history in the old forts, vast shopping malls, a photo opp at a Statue of Liberty and more excellent views from Fuji TV headquarters. Recommended for a day at least.

Always something new to do. I've yet to finish touring this small little man-made island and I plan to visit for a third time soon. There are plenty of shopping options, I would love to spend time in Round 1 entertainment trying out the in-door sports activities as it is something pretty novel to me. Absolutely adored the Gundam museum even though I understand nothing that was displayed, the chance to take a picture next to my favourite gundam character was a fabulous experience for a Gundam fan. The display of the various Gundam models had me drooling........ and the giant true-scale gundam outside diver city was amazing!!The toyota show room was amazing with the latest in the lexus range and the newest hybrids and various driving simulators. How I wish the cars here come with the detailed finishing that I see in the cars displayed there! there is a very nice car museum at Venus Fort that I spent lots of time in admiring the cars and snapping lots of pictures! There are a couple of there where people are allowed into the cars for photo taking, a must visit for car lovers!It is possible to visit the place many times as there are lots to do and something for everyone! Do plan carefully the route as the walk from one mall to another can be quite a distance especially when the wind and rain is causing a brain freeze.
So much to do!. A cool little part of Tokyo city and very easy to get to via the monorail. There is shopping and food everywhere! Great place to visit whilst in Tokyo.

One of Tokyo's most beautiful modern attractions. First of all, I must emphasize two things: 1) Odaiba is by all means enjoyed best at night, when all of its amazing hi-tech architecture is fully lit and decked out. 2) You MUST take the Yurikamome Line from Shinbashi Station and enjoy its amazing view of Tokyo. Once you're there, it's all eye candy: Huge shopping malls, a Statue of Liberty replica, the life-size Gundam statue, the enormous Fuji TV building, seaside views--I also happened to catch a beautiful Christmas tree in late January. Just about everything is connected by massive bridges surrounded by lights, only making Odaiba look even more like a "city of the future." It's flashy and big, but without the hustle and bustle of Shibuya or Shinjuku, and even with a bit of a romantic touch to it--just ask all the young couples present. You cannot visit Tokyo and not check Odaiba out.

Lifesize Gundam, BIG Sega arcade, European style mall!. There are sooo many attractions to visit in Odaiba. I believe you need a whole day to spend. The most famous attraction is the 18-m tall lifesize Gundam statue in front of Diver City Mall, this mall offers really complete shopping! You can get cute japanese souvenirs and chocolates. Inside they also have a maid cafe, 100yen store, 3 coins (300 yen store). Also don't forget to visit the Venus Fort European style shopping mall. For kids, there's Lego Exhibition centre, huge Sega arcade, and Madame Tussaud museum at the Aqua city mall. So many things you can do in Odaiba, definitely a good day out for everyone!
Good place for dates!. If you try to escape crowded places for a day Odaba is just right for you!Especially if you have a Date Odaba is one of the best places to go. Lots of stuff to do ;)

Great Island. Odaiba is a place you must visit if you come to Tokyo. This island has every thing that a tourist need to experience like shopping malls, ferris wheel, Toyota show room, a big Gundam and many more interesting attraction.The ticket of monorail to the island is actually more expensive compare to other public transport in Tokyo.

Worth it. Went to the mall and wasn't disappointed. I also went to the Gundam cafe and saw the HUGE gundam they have there (great for fans and kids alike). Got to ride the monorail and see rainbow bridge, statue of liberty replica and old tokyo tower

Definitely a 'must visit' while in Tokyo. Odaiba is definitely a must visit destination while you are in Tokyo for a holiday! Try to catch the amazing views while you are on the way either via train or by a cab. Fuji TV building, The freedom flame, the small statue of liberty, broadcasting center, the rainbow bridge (at night) and palette are must visit places in Odaiba.

Great shopping island and giant ferris wheel!. I took the Tokyo water bus from Asakusa to Odaiba and was pleasantly surprised. The water bus itself is a sight to see, and many sights to see along the river ride to Odaiba. Once there you will find 2 shopping malls as well as the Toyota showroom(very cool) and a giant ferris wheel. You can take a subway to many areas to/from Odaiba.

A bit of a hit and miss.. We travelled to Odaiba today as it was very rainy and cold so we thought it would be a safe bet as we assumed everything would be inside. The train ride took quite a while from Shinjuku, and trying to get the monorail back was crazy - we had to wait for the fourth train before we could squeeze in somewhere. It is about a five minute walk to Decks from the station. We were hungry and settled for the Ocean Shores Buffet Restaurant. I am not a fan of buffets but this one was reasonable. It included a selection of western, Asian, sushi and desserts all for around ¥1770. This is not cheap for Tokyo, but it isn't too expensive either. Decks was packed with locals and not many tourists. We went for a walk around after lunch but gave the attractions like Legoland and Joypolis a miss as they were quite expensive to visit. We also visited the Cat Cafe which was probably the weirdest experience of my life - it was ¥12000 per person for one hour in the cafe plus one drink. We decided to forgo to entry and just had look around the cat store, peaked through windows and listened to creepy cat music. I feel that you aren't missing out on much if you don't make it to Odaiba. The stores are pretty cool to look through but it isn't anything you wouldn't find anywhere else.

Fun and futuristic. Odaiba is great for manga, game and anime lovers! There are comic conventions and a multitude of manga and book shops, as well as a multitude of cool souvenir stores. There is also a spa hotel, and the scenery is nice.

Hi tech tokyo!. 1) the ride itself by monotrain from central Tokyo worth the visit. Try to seat in the front of the first car. 2) stunning day/night view of tokyo bay and rainbow bridge. 3) lots of restaurants, public spaces, shopping mall, tematic stores (disney, coca cola, etc) 4) no crowded as central tokyo area. We loved Odaiba and had a wonderful day out.

Unique views and plenty of shopping and eating. Odaiba offers a visually spectacular experience of Tokyo Bay and the Rainbow Bridge, together with several shopping malls crammed with a wide variety of retail outlets, cafes and restaurants, together with a few hotels too. Odaiba is the site of an old Japanese fort from which the Edo forces tried in vain to repel Commander Perry's 'black ships' in the mid 19th century. Odaiba is normally reached on the Yurikamome monorail which be taken from Shimbashi station at a price of Y310. If you have time, check out also the car museum near the Toyota showroom near Venusfort.

interesting island. lots to do, go to aqua city or fuji tv hq or diver city or big sight or the maritime museum or the museum of emerging technologies. Have a look at some of the largest parking lots you'll see in tokyo

One of y favourite place. A new place to explore in Tokyo. I like this place so much. Beside Gundam Front is there, you can find some shopping mall, the mini statue of liberty, a stunning view of tokyo city, rainbow bridge with tokyo tower, fuji tv building, megaweb, etc..

Worth the trip. Odaiba is worth the trip for sure.It's quite a trek and expensive on the monorail. Took us an hour to get there from our hotel in north tokyo.That said the monorail is a great ride in itself. The views are great from the cars. Try get a seat at the front as there's no driver in the way.In odaiba itself fit in the innovation museum and joypolis to make the trip over there extra worth it.

Lovely part of Tokyo. The bay is beautiful and this area is filled with interesting things to do. You could shop (it's not as crowded as in the city centre) and there's the cute Toyota museum place for you to explore. We also enjoyed the little Ferris Wheel as well!

Gundam Fans Unite!. If you want to feel like you've have taken a few steps closer to the future, Odaiba is the place to go. Shopping, food, and a giant Gundam will set you on the right path to having a good day. Gundam Front Tokyo is more of a museum, but the photo/video op of the moving Gundam outside and the IMAX Gundam story inside are a must. Akihabara also has a Gundam Cafe, but stop by Odaiba City... the metro ride out there provides great views for shutter bugs alike!

Beautiful hi-tech side of Tokyo. Going to this hi-tech side of Tokyo using hi-tech Himiko Boat from Asakusa Pier. What a complete experience. Love love love Odaiba. This is again what I imagine in mind what Tokyo is. Hi-tech. Minimalist. Well-designed building, architecture and public spaces. Love it. One of my fave part of Tokyo.

A great mix of theme parks, museums and leisure activities.. A great place to spend a relaxed day as there are three major shopping malls, museums and the FujiTV headquarters where you can reach the 25th floor and observe the city from above. Beautiful surroundings with views of the Rainbow bridge and the replica of Statue of Liberty. If you are into science the National Museum of Emerging Science (a.k.a Miraikan) is highly recommended as you will have an interactive experience and will see the Geo-Cosmos (a huge LCD globe) and the Asimo robot. Just note that the entrance fee is 600 Yen and the museum is closed every Tuesday.As I am a huge fan of Gundam series, went there to see the giant Gundam robot in front of the DiverCity Tokyo Plaza. The robot comes to life daily at 12:00, 15:00 and 17:00. Amazing experience if you are into this kind of stuff and totally worth the visit. Try to take the Yurikamome monorail line in order to reach the area as the trip above Tokyo Bay is amazing.
Fun place. Spent a whole day in Odaiba. We went to Gundam Front, Toyota Mega Web, Venus Fort and Tokyo Joypolis. Had so much fun!

Great Place to stay. A great place to stay even though a bit far from downtown Tokyo. With direct train links into downtown which is not that long but yet surrounded by 3 huge shopping malls & headquaters of Fuji Tv with its observation deck on 25th floor.

Absolutely loving. Just love this place! Can spend a whole day here with no problem. Perfect for pet lovers, u can enter t malls, restaurants (many of them) with your pets, u can take them for a walk by the beach...Things here r a little expensive, but t malls r really beautiful and huge. Really worth it ^^!! Perfect for couples and families ^^

Nothing special except if you are homesick from NYC. There is a replica of the Statue of Liberty to sooth the homesickness of NYkers other than that, it is just a convention center and showrooms place. Nothing special. Give it a miss if you have no time.

Kind of depressing. I'm surprised that so many people like it here...perhaps another indication that my husband and I aren't normal?The monorail ride out to Odaiba was really nice, with beautiful views of the city and the water. That's probably the nicest thing we can say about it. Since a lot of the attractions are relatively new, and the buildings/complexes so spread apart that walking between them is not really an option, and seemingly so geared toward conspicuous consumption (yes, even for Tokyo), we were completely turned off by it. We tried to stay as long as we could, walking through the Palette Town mall and the Toyota exhibition hall, and intended to go the Museum of Emerging Technology, but we couldn't leave fast enough.If you really, really like to shop (no judgement) you may find this area enjoyable since there are several shopping centers. It just wasn't our bag.

Interesting place, but time it based on why you're going. This was an interesting half day trip to see something different in Tokyo. We took the Yurikamome which is highly recommended - a great way to see Tokyo. If you're looking to 'do' things, don't get there before 11am as most shops/amusements/restaurants etc will be closed. We were going to have a look around, so it didn't bother us that quite a few things were closed. I can suggest the big Ferris Wheel for a great view (opens at 10.30am) and Venus Fort is well worth a look inside for the interior design. A nice place to get out of the hustle and bustle of Tokyo and see a different side.

Don't be an early bird. Nobody told us that hardly anything opened before 1100am! We finally found a coffee shop at 0900 and left by 1030 after walking the whole closed 'megacomplex'. The photo ops were good though especially the Fuji TV building.
Lots of big department stores, great shopping!. We stayed at Nikko Tokyo Hotel in Odaiba. Beautiful views of the bay. very relaxing!Lots of interesting things to do and close to Disney Resort!

Kinda sparse Gundam rules. Kind of not completely occupied city. The TV station building was great but what they let us see was a why did we go there. The stores where Gundam was were modern and was fun Gundam was fantastic, the museum was ok, the other store was not bad. we dined at the hotel near the train station odaiba food was not bad and for Tokyo decent prices. mildly surprised

A beautiful afternoon. Reaching Odaiba at around 3 in the afternoon, just enjoying the sun go down and the city lights come up along the bay area. As a photographer, I totally enjoyed the location as it provided me with numerous photo possibilities ... the bay, rainbow bridge, boats, the beach ...
amazing.. I really like this place. I advice you to go to the shopping mall in front of imitation of Liberty monument and go to Tabehodai in 4th floor and enjoy eating with a very amazing view.

Interesting area. Odaiba is situated on the waterfront and is a nice daytrip within Tokyo. In the area is an outlet mall (which unfortunately was closed the day we went), a shopping centre on the waterfront, the Fuji TV building and a Toyoto "MegaWeb" car showroom which showcases their new and concept cars. The place looks a bit rundown and stuck in the 1990's, which was disappointing to see. It felt a bit like a rundown version of Sydney's Darling Harbour or NYC's Coney Island. One of the only ways to reach this area is via the expensive Yurikamone line, which is a private, driverless monorail which goes over the Rainbow Bridge.The view from here of the city is very nice, especially during the sunset. Otherwise, I was a bit disappointed with the area.

Best view to see sunset. The Daibas - an artificial set of islands originally set up to protect the harbor - is the place to see the city skyline. There is an artificial beach towards the city, with some restaurants and bars towards there. Toyota's "Mega Web" is interesting if you like cars. Else there are plenty of very nice, big shopping malls, with interesting things to explore.

Cool attractions. Odaiba was a good day trip. We saw the fake Statue of Liberty, walked the boardwalk, got terrified of the ginormous bees (seriously, they were HUGE!) and saw Venus Fort, the mall that looks like Venice well worth a trip - even though we weren't shopping!) We also went up the Fuji TV building to see the view, although most of the TV stuff was lost on us as we don't watch Japanese TV. Great view though, if a bit pricey. We also wanted to go to the Museum of Future Science and Innovation but it was closed on Tuesday. Sadface. All in all a good day, but it was VERY hot and there's little shade other than AC'd malls, so beware if it's a super hot day.

Unbelievable area. The most attracting spot in Tokyo. You can enjoy watching artificial Island containing the giants of Japanese industry on a driver less monorail passing over and through the towers of that city. strongly suggested.

Venus fort is impressive, Odaiba is futuristic. Wow. Statue of liberty in Tokyo? Shopping mall that looks like Venice? Good for 1/2 day. I wasn't that impressed by the Megaweb but that island makes for a nice afternoon visit.

Like a huge, American mall, mainly targeted at locals. This was good to see to say I saw it, but it wasn't an experience I'd be clamoring for again. If you're familair with Navy Pier in Chicago, think of it as that x10. Most of the shops have a seaside American town theme, and this place looks to be mainly an attraction for the locals. I'm kind of used to that sort of think, you may not be and want to check it out. There's also the life-sized Gundam statue which is pretty amazing.

From Science to Shopping, Odaiba has something for everyone!. I spent a whole day on the man-made island of Odaiba. From the exciting Miraikan Science Centre to admiring the beautiful Fuji TV building, to walks along the Marine Park, photographing the Rainbow Bridge, Gundam, and shopping... Odaiba has quite a bit on offer. The many retail outlets, museums, science centres, theme parks, attractions, giant Gundam statue, and even a replica of the Statue of Liberty... it's a day's worth of stuff all in one place. And just like the rest of Tokyo, easily accessible via public transport (although the local trains here are a little bit more expensive than the JR lines).

Crazy place to be during summer. Too many people and overly crowded, the malls were so pack, every attraction within the 2km radius was packed with people. Plus the humid weather makes it so difficult to walk and breathe with the crowd.

Eh.... We had half a day to visit Tokyo before our long flight home, and so we spent it in Odaiba. Lots of shopping, eating, and amusement... but not much else. If where you live doesn't have much in the way of shopping, eating, and amusement, you will probably enjoy it. Otherwise, I would skip it. There was nothing bad, just not the reason you visit Japan.I did enjoy the large Toyota display, and the Toyota old-car museum.

Very interesting area to visit. Must go if you have a spare day in tokyo.. We planned one of our days to visit Odaiba and Asakusa and we were glad we got ti make it! We left our hotel in rhe morning and take the metro to shimbashi and then connected to the Automated Yurikamome line. Be sure to get in the most front seat so you could see the panoramic view of tokyo. The train takes you on the famous rainbiw bridge and to odaiba. We got iff at Aomi station, spent 2 hours at the Venus Fort, a nice italian style shopping mall. Venus fort is adjacent to the mega web, toyota car showroom which i am sure my boy would love it there but we didn't have tume to visit. Then we took the train back to the Odaiba Aqua City another big shopping mall with toys r us and babies r us store and a big 100 yen shop in the 4 th floor. We took the water taxi (boat) back to asakusa (the pier was just a short walk from the odaiba aqua city mall be sure to check the time because the boat runs on schedule) for our evening visit to the sensoji temple. This turned out to be a fun day fir the whole family. Strongly recommended especially on your visit when it's rainning or hot outside.

Amazing. Spend a day here if you can. Loved the area but you will see American stores here so if you want to avoid such, don't come. Otherwise, you will be amazed at the architecture in Odaiba and Ariake. Seems like the various architects were trying to one up each other here. They are futuristic. The one thing I've noticed in Japan is that they do a lot of building teardowns to make way for newer buildings. Hope they don't do the same for many of these buildings. If you want to catch a flick, there's Mediage (connected to Aqua City). Aqua City has many restaurants. The restaurant floors look like a theme park as you walk through it. Not your typical mall.

Thoughts on Odaiba. Likes: A great place to get away from the claustrophobia in Central Tokyo, Akihabara, Shinjuku and Shibuya. Panoramic view of the Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo Bay.Dislikes: The expensive admission rates to the amusement parks.
Nice, but there are a lot of people. It's perfect to spend half day, maybe more if you go relaxed. But there is nothing special and should not go if you will spend few days at Tokyo.

Take the Boat!. I traveled with my seven year old daughter. We stayed at the Hotel Richmond in Asakusa and took the Water Bus (suijo basu) to Odaiba. It was about an hour or so on the boat and although the Tokyo skyline is not really spectacular from the water in the daytime, it was a really nice new boat and a very smooth ride. I get seasick standing in a pool sometimes and this was fine. Landing in Odaiba you see a short wading beach (no swimming allowed). My daughter played here for over an hour. Definitely recommend carrying extra clothing. I didn't so I ended up replacing my daughter's soaked shorts with something dry from The Gap in Aqua City shopping complex directly behind the beach. There are a few such complexes in the area...we walked to the DiverCity complex a block behind Aqua City to check out H&M and Old Navy. I know it sounds crazy but we live here in Japan and finding inexpensive and interesting clothing for kids is like finding gold. My daughter liked the interactive wall in the food court of DiverCity. It takes a steady stream of photographs and puts the pictures up on a big wall where they float around for a while. If your kid is a poser, you will be here a long time. Don't forget to check out the giant Gundam replica. The robot is cool but looking at the people worshipping it from below is kind of fun too...even if you're not a fan. If you're staying in Asakusa a round trip boat ride to Odaiba is a great day out, away from the crowded trains of Tokyo.

Great spot. Spend the day doing everything here, great for families. Ride the monorail and be amazed at how you are crossing the bay with traffic. Spend time at Legoland and the Decks area, ride the tallest ferris wheel in the world, have a look at the Toyota showroom, shop at the outlet mall and so the list goes on. Full day, not a minute to spare.

Tokyo view, Liberty replica and more. Odaiba is actually a really large area, so to be more specific: I'm talking about the area around the "Daiba" station on the Yurikamome line. Here you can get a SPECTACULAR view of Tokyo with the rainbow bridge in front, I just hope you have a camera that can do that view justice, especially at night. There is also a replica of the Statue of Liberty, it's also interesting. This is a really place for a date or just some gorgeous sight seeing. For shopping/food, there is a shopping center right next to this place, so you're set for a couple of hours here. Fuji TV building is also a pretty interesting architectural sight.

Diverse entertainment area with a good variety of things to do. This is a good place to go to spend a day and get out of the typical foreign tourist route in Tokyo. The whole area is set up as an entertainment district, meaning there is pretty much sure to be something for everyone. I went with my 10-year old and spent the day visiting Legoland, the Toyota showroom and visiting the batting cages, ping-pong tables and arcades in Leisureland. There are a ton of restaurants and shopping opportunities in the various mall complexes, meaning you could easily spend a day here and find something to keep yourself interested. I'm sure some of the attractions are hit and miss, but none of them are going to take more than a couple of hours, meaning there's always a chance to redeem a mistake a little later.The train ride over on the Yurikamome line is nice as well, as it gives you a chance to go across the Rainbow bridge and get a great view of Tokyo Bay.

great view of rainbow bridge & gundam statue. nice place for a day trip frm Tokyo, the new Diver City shopping mall suit those who prefer shopping, there's a Gundam statue at the back of the building that offer a 5-10mins show 3-4 times daily, a newly open Legoland Discovery Center for the kids & a great nite view of the rainbow bridge with Tokyo Tower lite up at nite

Worth an afternOon here. The beach, the rainbow bridge, futuristic buildings and some shopping.. Worth at least an afternoon. Easily accessible by trains. You can even visit the hot spring theme park here.

Nice boat ride to get there, little else to recommend it. You can take a boat down the Sumida River from Asakusa to Obaida ... the best way to get there. Then take the subway back to the JR line at Shinbashi Station. On Obaida, you can wander around a not so great mall, have drinks on the outdoor patio at the Nikko Hotel, ride the elevator up to the Big Ball at the Fuji Building and see one of the weirder - not in a good way - exhibits you will ever see. Don't go if you don't have much time in Tokyo.

OK. Not really much to see on Odaiba. The statue of liberty is a bit if a gimmick. The boat journey over is worth it though as you get some nice views of that part of Tokyo. Also on the Yamanote line.

Full of surprises from all the malls. Love the concepts of the different malls. There's Venus Fort, Palette Town where you can visit the antique car showroom, Hello Kitty. You can even see a miniature statue of liberty & they even have an Huge Onsen town.

Nice sightseeing. This was our first evening in Tokyo , we were tired but wanted to see something of Tokyo so we took the monorail ride of Obaida and enjoyed it ! This feels like a former World Expo site like we have seen in Seattle , Montreal , Shangai and Barcelona but it is much bigger and there are people living there ! It is a mix of condotowers, museums , company headquarters , thematic parks, aquariums , restaurants , concert halls .... all built in a futuristic style ! INTERESTING !!!

Fun fun fun. It's a great place to hang out. Besides the play place for kids, we really enjoyed seeing the statue of freedom, which is just like the stair of liberty in new York, but smaller. For some reason this was not mentioned in any tour booms, my husband had been here before so we visited. Great photo opportunities here with the bridge in the back, also great for evening shots, we even got Tokyo tower in the background. Ride the monorail, so fun and convenient.
Good to see.. A trip to Japan would not be complete without a visit to the harbour.The monorail day ticket is a must and you can get on and off as many times as you like.
Really fun place to hang out. Nice to spend a day trip here, cool place to hang out and lots of fun things to do and see, and shopping too!

I would have given this a miss... If shopping and entertainment is your thing, this is a good place to be. However, given what the rest of Tokyo has to offer, we do regret spending half a day here. On 20/20 hindsight, this is what we would have done: 1) Go to Odaiba on the Sumida River Cruise. This 1-hour cruise is so much more worth it compared to the laughable World Heritage Cruise in Hiroshima. 2) See Odaiba from the train. The JR Yurikamome line circles the island. Would have saved us tonnes of time and legwork.The shopping complexes are choked full of international brands. The only special shop that caught our attention is the Cats and Dogs specialty shop in Aqua-City.
I love to look over, but. we are @ quake country. Just in case, better stay away from those newly developed area.
Nice !. The statue of liberty is there! hahaha good for sight seeing.

lots of shops, pretty cheesy but fun. Get a day pass if travelling there by train.. definitely better value than single or return tickets.. huge malls for shopping if that's your thing and worth a milch around!

Ok, but much more to do in Tokyo. We visited this area as part of a full day tour. to be honest we were a little tired by the time we got here and it was mid week, so that may explain why it was so quiet. There is a shopping mall (go play with the cats on the basement floor!) with the usual shops. If i went back to Tokyo i wouldn't be rushing back to Odaiba, but i would recommend it if you have some spare time
Not really seeing Japan. It is a new area with new shopping mall etc...views and eating are great but need to access the sights by monorail and train.

Lazy day. On a nice day, after you've seen everything else you wanted to see in Tokyo, Odaiba is a pretty good place to go. There's a nice long man-made beach. Many shops and restaurants in the area. Huge mall. There's a free shuttle bus that has stops at all the places throughout the island, so saves you some time. Beautiful views of Rainbow Bridge and of some of the Tokyo Skyline during sunset.
Trade Shows, Shopping and Night Life. This area holds Tokyo Big Site - many international trade show venue and many shopping complexs with hotels, attractions and nice restaurant sand bars.

Surprise in Tokyo Bay. well off the beaten path in reclaimed land in Tokyo Bay - but easily reached by a tram car (Yurikamome Line) going across the Rainbow Bridge connecting to the Shinagawa subway station.Walk along the bay a mixed use area - science and maritime museums, more of the endless Tokyo shopping malls and shops, and a giant showroom of Toyota vehicles and an automotive museum.(both free) . You can buy a unlimited use day pass and jump off and on the tram lien to get around
Take the monorail for ride over rainbow bridge.. Good photo oportunities of Rainbow bridge and Tokyo skyline at night. Shopping mall with food outlets. Nice place to sit in the sun.
Must visit place when you're coming Tokyo. Located in Tokyo Bay, you can reach there via Yurikamome line train cross over the sea. Lots of nice places and famous for Japanese teenager dating.

Little bit of everything. Odaiba is the "Fun Zone" for Tokyoites. I've been there several times, once I saw a large Gundam statue and another time I went to the Edo Period theme onsen. I high recommend the onsen, it's like an onsen theme park but in all edo era design. You can choose a Yukata to wear around the theme area.

Man made!. Easy to get to from Shimbashi station using the Yurikamome Line across Rainbow Bridge. .... and return via water bus! Many sights to see! Nice beach with excellent eating close by in Aqua City. Excellent shopping in the Decks plus further round the rail track at the Mall. The Ferris wheel provides excellent views of Tokyo. Take a driving test in Toyodas showroom with its own track!

A day trip option. If you are in Tokyo for a week, it is worth visiting Odaiba. Taking the monorail was convenient and reminded me of the Disney monorail. The range of shops were the same as in other parts of Tokyo. Sega World was closed for refurbishment much to the disappointment of my 12 year old and there were no postings nor announcements that this was closed until you actually get there. Sony Explorer Center was expensive and had limited things to see, same with the Miraikan Science Center. Venus Fort for dining and shopping and the Toyota Center were good places to visit. It was raining most of the day and quite cold so it was a pain to go from one area to another even on a day pass using the monorail; however, we still enjoyed the day trip and would recommend it if you have a day to spare.
Worth coming to Odaiba just for the Onsen. The onsen is beautiful - truly enjoyed it. If I was ever to come back to the Tokyo area, I would come to this onsen again.
the my hung out place. coz its so peaceful and the view esp. smell of ocian remind me of my old countryhome and near at disneyland .............

worth visiting. After reading some reviews of the place, I thought this will be a place of little interest since we don't have young children. I was pleasantly surprised and look forward to visiting again with plenty of time to explore all the island has to offer. We enjoyed everything, from the shopping to the toyota center...and wish we had more time to spend there. The Views from the big wheel are spectacular!

My favorite place in Tokyo. This neighborhood is my favorite in Tokyo. It is not overly crowded and also has nice sunset view. The malls also has some nice places to eat. Visit in the late afternoon if you can as it can be quite romantic. However, winter visit is not recommended.

Shopping, museums and onsen.. A real mix. Depends what you like. The shopping setting is great but it is the usual range of shops - nothing unique. The museums are good but a little specialised - if you are into boats then it is perfect. the onsen is large and fun but very touristy and really expensive. Nice seaside walks.

A little overrated but worth seeing.. Quite a large place with a number of large shopping malls, massive ferris wheel and Toyota megaweb. The train over the rainbow bridge offers great views can be a little pricey. The area is larger than we expected.
Breathtaking. Very nice place from toyota web to rainbow bridge. Very friendly for all ages.

Nice day trip from Tokyo. Should try Water Bus (Tokyo Cruise) if Sunny. Lots of photogenic spots. Within a day you can enjoy Fuji Television Building (You can go up to the ball shaped observation floor to have a perfect view including Tokyo Sky Tree and Tokyo Tower), Decks Tokyo Beach (Retro shopping mall and Trick Art Museum). Recommend to go there on Sunny Day. I brought my daughter who's 8 years and she was really excited.

Waterfront, space, fresh air, something for the city dwellers.. Very innovative and smart idea to create such an “island” at Tokyo Bay for the citizens who live in Tokyo. A good weekend “getaway” for groups, lovers, families or even solo.One day is barely enough or not enough to visit all the interesting buildings, shopping malls, theme parks, showrooms, museums and one may need to be selective. I usually started my “day trip” to this district in the morning, so that I can fully enjoy the changing scene for the whole day. My favorite items in this district included: 1.The scenic ride from the “driverless” Yurikamome monorail (departed from the Shimbashi station,) so carefree, so comfortable, so convenient. With a day pass, I enjoyed many in and out as I wished. (Better go there during weekdays, not the weekends…)2.The Fuji Television Building, so much fun to see the TV production related activities, and the real stage that TV stars rehearse (eg. SMAP X SMAP); taking pictures, and there were always special events for celebration on special occasions. Meet the star if you are lucky. 3.The decks, love it in the summer.4.The Venus Fort Shopping Mall, beautifully designed to remind people of Las Vegas. With indoor “blue sky ceilings” and “Roman fountains”, you can find some nice French and Italian fashions, and locally made, trendy jewelries. 5.The Rainbow Bridge.6. Watch the Giant Ferris Wheel at night.
easy to get around, lots to see. Worth a trip, the views of the Rainbow Bridge are amazing, and the shopping is great. Be sure to check out the Venus Fort shopping mall!

walking the rainbow bridge to Odaiba. walking on the rainbow bridge (great view over the harbour), along the beach towards the Miraikan exhibition (600yen), taking pics at the liberty statue and relaxing while walking around the area

Futuristic. Odaiba is Tokyo in the future. The buildings all look like a science fiction movie; and they also have the Toyota showroom, the Fuji Television building, and Aqua City. Odaiba is a prefect getaway from Tokyo and a breath of fresh air. the monorail that takes u there is like a roller coaster with some amazing view of tokyo. The National museum of emerging science and innovation and the Tokyo Big Sight buildings are so beautiful you'd be mesmerized just staring at it all day long.

Venus Fort, Megaweb, ferris wheel, and Decks. I've been to Odaiba on a few separate trips to Japan, its a nice little getaway from the busy Tokyo city. The places of interest are Venus Fort, Megaweb, and the Decks. Venus Fort and Megaweb are part of "Palette Town." Venus Fort is a shopping complex that (inside) looks very similar to the Venetian in Las Vegas. Theres lots of clothing stores and restaurants here.Megaweb is right next door to Venus Fort, it's a huge Toyota car showroom. Theres always something interesting to see: the newest cars, sport cars, prototypes, and even a simulation where you go into a movie theatre room to get a race car experience. It's really neat here!! Free admission too, can't go wrong.Don't forget the huge ferris wheel on your way in. It's ok, nothing spectacular but you do get a nice view of Odaiba. Your pic is taken right before you go on, and you can purchase the pic at the end if you want for like 6000yen (kinda expensive, but I thought my bf and I took a nice pic so I bought it for memories sake hehe). I forget how much it costs to ride the ferris wheel, after the first time I did I didn't have the urge to do it again on later visits.Last but not least, the Decks is outside of "Palette Town" but hard to miss. You see it before going into "Palette Town" - it's the shopping complex with the Sega logo on one side. There's a nice variety of shops in here, but the best part is walking through to the actual decks - there's a really nice view here! Really relaxing and great for some pic taking.

A Good Break from Temples and Palaces. I planned Odaiba as part of our Tokyo stay as a break from the temples and to see a modern side of Japan. It was a FUN place for my eight year old son with arcades and stores for the younger crowd. If you have younger children with you, they will enjoy Odaiba Palette Town. The giant ferris wheel wasn't so great but it gave us a 15 minute rest from the walking around and to relax a bit. Very easy to get to, one train from Shibuya Station to Tokyo Teleport. Lot of young couples and groups of teens playing at the arcadeS (more than one) and lots of families with school aged children. It's completely safe there, when you exit the Tokyo Teleport station, Palette Town is on one side of the island and Decks and Aqua City is on the other side. Start at Palette Town and walk over to Decks just before sunset for pictures and dinner so you can see Rainbow Bridge lit up in the dark.

Very nice place, especially at night. Odaiba looks like a futuristic place. All the buildings look very space out from one another. It create an atmosphere of wide space.Odaiba houses some attractions like the Toyota showroom, the Fuji Television which has an observatory tower, Aqua City with a view of Rainbow bridge etc.It also has a Statue of Liberty by the water.Odaiba can be walk from one building to another within the area of Fuji Television and the Toyota Showroom. If you want to go to Panasonic Center, you will need to take the train.The Rainbow bridge lights has been turned off at the moment. Despite this, it is still a place worth exploring.

A must see when in Tokyo. I visited Odaiba in early March during my stay in Tokyo. Nearest station is Tokyo Teleport, some construction work is currently underway around the area which means they have cut off some paths so you end up walking in circles a bit!Venus Fort is a fantastic shopping centre. It is so beautifully designed and you really do feel like you are in Italy. The shops offer discount on foreign nationals but only if you present your passport. You can cross to the other side toward the Statue of Liberty using the walkthrough, although this was being renovated to we used the station as a walk through no problem. There are several restaurants above the river where we had a meal and sat outside watching tokyo get dark, the views or the skyline and rainbow bridge are breath taking. Will upload pics but you need to see for yourself, nothing compares!Also would recommend paying 900 yen to go on the big wheel for views rather than the 2000 at tokyo tower, you are presented the same views at half the price.

Fabulous and futuristic. I heart Odaiba. Its unfinished. Its avant-garde architecture. It has loads of things to do. And the trains going there don't have drivers, how freaking cool is that! Its filled with museums, awesome architecture, shopping malls, greenery, an onsen and not forgetting views of Fuji-san too! Most importantly, it has the Statue of Liberty so don't go all the way to NYC to catch that :DSo do go there and spend a blissful day or even two for that matter. :)

Venus Fort. For your real Japan experience visit this shopping center that is supposed to resemble a medieval European village. It has been renovated recently and it is located next to the train stop Aomi.

The Future is Here. One of the most unique place in a unique town. The aw begins already with the "Shuto Expressway" line to Odaiba overlooking Tokyo skyline. The architecture is very special everywhere you turn your gaze. Each building has its own charm and style with highlights including th Tokyo Dig Sight building, Fuji TV with nice views, Toyota showcase, huge ferries wheel and the Venus Port shopping mall. A full day should be allocated for this great area.

great place for young people. I loved Odaiba. Me and my brother, 21 and 23, went via the yurikamome which was ok, not too interesting. We first went to the toyota showroom which was interesting, went to the mall next to it, in pallete town which was great. Had lunch at a wonderful italian place and then went to the mall next to joypolis which was really cool with litte shops selling weird things. I espcially loved the ones selling all japanese candy, you could find everything in them! i can't wait to go back..

Pretty disappointing. We went to Odaiba as part of a trip with teens focused exclsuively on the contemporary dynamism in Tokyo (no shrines, etc.) Odaiba was easily the most disappointing aspect of an otherwise terrific trip. The Panasonic showroom had a huge display on paleontology (we are already are quite familiar with this topic). Our tour guide insisted we spend alot of time in the mall; we were unable to enter the Fuji TV studio. The mini Statue of Liberty was amusing, and very Japanese, but even the train was only mildly interesting. (The Shinkansen still thrills, however.) I'd save Odaiba for a rainy day.

Tufuristic City. Odaiba is a hottest new tourism spot in Tokyo. It is futuristic artificial city built on top of the Tokyo Bay land-fill. We visited there via Yurikamome Line. It is totally computerized train. No train conductors at all. There are multiple shopping malls, museums and parks, so you can enjoy a whole day there. I recommend to visit there to see how high tech city Tokyo is.
